dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER, mid 40’s, vacant, lies in bed fully dressed in a and tie. The voice we hear belongs to THE BEAVER. He has a crisp English accent.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a picture of Walter Black, a hopelessly depressed individual. He wants you to know he’s tried everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a shelf of SELF HELP TITLES. Walter pulls down DUMPING DEPRESSION. CLOSE ON a medicine cabinet full of prescriptions. Walter pops some pills. WALTER CHANTS and pounds as part of a drum circle. WALTER SOBS on a park bench. WALTER HITS himself with a belt but refuses to show emoti WALTER POPS more pills. WALTER READS from THE RAINBOW INSIDE. WALTER LAYS on a couch, speaking to his therapist. WALTER STARES into a hypnotist’s pocketwatch. WALTER POPS a whole handful of pills.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a night stand where a copy of SIX STEPS TO A NEW lies open. In bed beside it, Walter sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But, mostly what he does is sleep. An ALARM goes off. He slaps it dead.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: WALTER GETS into bed. It’s still daylight. Kids play outs WALTER SLEEPS on a couch, mid-afternoon. WALTER SLEEPS at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prefers to call it siesta. He dreams of islands with bright buildings and wandering dogs. WALTER SLEEPS in his car.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Places where the Dursuit of slumber is a local custom. WALTER SLEEPS in a fast food restaurant. A WORKER pokes h

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rather than a sign of intractable clinical depression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at his desk. He stares at a photo of his fami THE BEAVER (V.O. Two things keep Walter from sleeping forever. CLOSE ON the photo. Walter, the wife, two boys. More on t later.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One is his family, which sleeps only at night and regards those who do otherwise with suspicion. NEW ANGLE reveals that the room is full of people. On the far wall, THE VP, late 30’s, sharp, motions to a chart. All the lines aim down. All the eyes turn to Walte

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The other is that he’s the CEO of a once-proud toy company-

dialogues.speaker: FLASH TO
dialogues.text: INT. FINE RESTAURANT —- NIGHT DAVY CONYERS, former CEO sits across from an ESCORT. Davy starts to CHOKE.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: - whose founder died unexpectedly, and left Walter in charge. Davy goes face down on the table. THUD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter’s since led them to the edge of bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENRY, adorable, fragile- tooking third grader, sits alon staring straight ahead while other kids TALK and play. THE BEAVER (V.O. What he’s done to the company is just the start. His depression is an ink that stains all who touch him. A black hole that swallows all who get near. A wad of mashed potatoes SPLATS next to Henry. Other kids LAUGH. If Henry notices, he doesn’t show it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Henry, his youngest, has become, what his teachers call, ‘hermit like’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PORTER, cute but wild haired emo teen, sits at his desk, reading. tBhe books around him have titles’ like: DNA=DES He stares into a notebook labeled JOURNAL OF SIMILARITIES It’s some sort of list with fifty something items like: Fingernail Digging, Whistle Breathing, Finger-Chin Tap. THE BEAVER (V.O. Porter, his oldest, has begun to openly lobby for a divorce... We push past Porter towards his wall where there’s a deep head_sized dent in the drywall. We close in on the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH_IN on the refrigerator, where photos of two differen middle aged bachelors are stuck with magnets.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: and leave hints that his mother could easily find a replacement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEREDITH, late 30’s with late 20’s looks, WEEPS among wom who practically have Soccer Mom tattooed on their forehea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith, his wife, has clung to hope that he’1l one day wake up, snap out of it. She reaches into her purse for a tissue, but ends up with another of Porter’s bachelor photos. She puts it back, ta a napkin from one of the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is laying in bed, dressed as we first found him.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But he hasn’t. And she’s finally decided that he is a weight she and the kids can no longer carry. Meredith appears in the doorway. Walter looks over at her gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the self help books being packed into a box. CLOSE ON the medications being swept into another box. CLOSE on the boxes being loaded into a packed trunk. The is closed, revealing a car stuffed to the gills.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V-0-)
dialogues.text: She does the only thing left to do- INT. WALTER’S CAR Walter gets in. He looks into his side mirror and sees Meredith CRYING in the driveway behind him. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - and says the only thing left to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes connect. It’s awkward. Do you wave when you’re being thrown out? He begins to massage his eyebrows with thumb and forefinger. Finally, he puts the car in drive. She crosses her arms, swallows her tears. As she watches him drive away...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter sits across from JARED, a confused athletic type.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Cc minus! Porter grabs a paper off the desk, waves it at Jared.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Jared, you're failing the class. And this writing sample could probably get you committed in several states. You really think you can suddenty hand in an A paper and get away with it?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: But I can get a fucking C-!

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Excellent. Good luck to you. Porter starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: What about Hector? You just got him an A in Family Development. Porter starts to massage his eyebrows exactly as we saw Walter do. Realizing it, he suddentl, stops and disciplin himself by SNAPPING a big rubber band on his wrist. Frustrated, he takes out his Journal of Similarities notebook. As he adds Massaging Eyebrows to the list...

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’ve never written anything for Hector. If he told you different he’s a_liar. (closing his notebook) But hypothetically, if I had written Hector an A paper, it certainly wouldn’t have been right out of the box. Hypothetically, he would have come_to me a long time ago, and we would have raised his rades incrementally. And he would ave been responsible for memorizing the facts in the papers I wrote so that he wouldn’t miss test questions over the same information. And if that had happened, then yes, he might have turned in an A paper and he might even be making a solid B in a class he used to be failing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, if someone else was asking me to do this for them, to not only write them a paper, but to do it as them, with their voice, at their skill level, then I would say that they could either do it my way or they could take their chances buying some piece of shit off the internet. Jared thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: 150 every time?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (sing-song) Responsible regulars receive reduced rates. Porter slides a book across the table. Jared SIGHS. He op it, puts $150 in and slides it back. Porter nods and stan

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: I gotta pass this class to graduate you know?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Wilkins, from your team last year? The one who thought the words igneous and ignorant were interchangeable? Where’s he now?

dialogues.speaker: JARED
dialogues.text: Playing for OSU. Porter nods.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You’ll get the grades. All you have to do is make people believe they’re yours. Porter walks away. NORAH, cheerleader outfit, the kind of girl you're either hopelessly in love with, hopelessly jealous of, or both, breaks away from friends to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah glides in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Hey. Porter’s look says they don’t normally talk. He keeps mov

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I can’t say hey to you?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You can, you just never have.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Well, I’m... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Really? I’m not. Without warning, Porter stops at his locker. She takes a steps before realizing it. She comes back. He seems annoy

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously, what do you want? She’s taken aback by the hostility. A beat. NORAH ; ; I... need you to write something. Porter LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I knew it. Is this what passes for undercover around here? You’re the fucking valedictorian. He reall thinks I’m going to fall for this?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Mumphry, or whichever vice principal sent you. You tell him I’m insulted. Porter closes his locker, starts away. She grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Hey! Will you hold on for a second? Porter grudgingly stops.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one sent me. I really need help.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You have a 4.0. I’m eight places behind - ou in the class rank. I copy. O: ygu in calculus. Why on Babin’ wou d you want me to write you a paper?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: It’s not a paper. (quiet) It's... my graduation speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t usually say this, but save your money « No one pays attention to those things. He starts to go. She grabs him again.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, my parents will be paying attention, so... I hear, not that_I’m saying you write other eople’s papers, but if you did, I ear you really make yourself sound like them. Get? in their heads. That’s what I need. Porter considers this. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’d need some samples and- She quickly hands him a paper from her bag.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I have this now and I can get you more by tomorrow. Porter looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I see one i dotted with a heart and we're done. He starts away.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You really copy off me in calculus? Without looking back...

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Don’t forget to bring cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith waits in SUV gridlock outside the elementary sch She scans the crowd but can’t find Henry. Suddenly, the passenger door opens and, seemingly from nowhere, petite Henry hoists himself in.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You passed me again.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I was looking.  Henry shrugs. His to drive.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How was your day? Another shrug.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you talk to anyone?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: New person or old person?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: New.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Good. What did you talk about?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) He said I was a ball licker and I told him I wasn’t and he threw me in the dumpster. Meredith is aghast. Henry shows no emotion.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What! Did you tell your teacher?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She got me out of the dumpster. demeanor is very quiet, flat. As she starts Meredith suppresses her urge to cry as if she’s been trai calms her voice, and says something that sounds rehearsed Henry nods as if he’s also heard She looks question.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: This is why the doctor wants you_to focus on coming out of your shell. When you spend so much time alone, the other kids see you as a target.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Is Dad gone? it before. A silent beat. at him, trying to measure how he feels about this Henry gives nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: He’s not gone dear. We just agreed that it’s better for us all if we don't live together anymore. §eeat) How does that make you feel?  10. Henry shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter comes out with two large bags of CLINKING liquor. he gets to the car he realizes there’s no room for them. CLOSE ON Walter’s trunk being opened. CLOSE ON a dumpster. Boxes are tossed in. We see that the the ones full of self help books and medication. Clothes follow. Files. Awards. Yearbooks. A set of golf clubs. NEW ANGLE shows Walter emptying the final items out of th backseat. He throws them in the dumpster. Walter stares at what he’s done, his life mixed in with t garbage. He looks sleepy. He leaves, then stops, slowly comes back, eyeing somethin ANGLE ON the garbage reveals a half buried BEAVER PUPPET, large plastic eyes staring out from under some refuse. Walter squints, then reaches for it. It turns out to have large bushy tail and big happy grin. He holds it up. He and the beaver seem to stare blankly at one another fo long time, as if each reading a story in the other’s eyes CLOSE ON the trunk again as the two large bags full of li are tossed into the now empty space. A beat, then.... The beaver puppet is tossed in too. The lid SLAMS down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON the bed as we hear the DOOR OPEN, the BOTTLES be set on the ground. Suddenly Walter falls into bed with his shoes on. He pull pillow over his head. He sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a wreck. Sheets, clothes, empty bottles. ANGLE ON a bottle of sleeping pills, opened and half gone follow a trail of the little pink pills until we come to.  11. WALTER, sitting on the floor shooting whiskey straight, t beaver puppet now on his left hand. He’s WEEPING. On the TV, Alan Thicke is having a heart to heart with Ki Cameron in a GROWING PAINS episode...

dialogues.speaker: ALAN THICKE
dialogues.text: (on tv) This is a very special place Mike. My father built this cabin by hand.

dialogues.speaker: KIRK CAMERON
dialogues.text: (on tv) Wow! No tools or anything? Cool! This seems very profound to Walter. Still CRYING, he LAUG along with the audience and moves toward the TV, hugs it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (drunk) Beautiful. He takes a shot of whiskey and then pours some on the scr as if pouring it down Alan Thicke’s throat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go. ANGLE ON the TV again as Walter continues pouring whiskey the screen. Alan and Kirk hug. Something breaks in Walter. He drops the bottle. A dong beat as he looks around the room, his face suddenl ank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has fashioned a necktie into a noose around the sh rod. He SOBS as he steps up onto the edge of the bathtub, knee bent, and tightens it around his neck. He takes a few deep breaths and closes his eyes. A long b He inches his feet to the very edge of the bathtub and th finally, lets them slip off. His weight drops onto the noose, but it suspends him for barely a second before the whole rod comes down, dropping into the tub backwards with a tremendous CRASH. His feet hang out of the tub, the rest of him invisible, motionless.  12. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON the shower rod as it DRAGS across the carpet. Reveal Walter, still fastened to the rod by his tie, trud toward the balcony. Drops of blood dot the back of his sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter puts a chair next to the railing, climbs UP. He ta rickety steps up until he’s balanced very tenuously on th edge of the railing. He looks down, a solid ten stories. The tie pulling at his neck, the shower rod hanging behin him, BANGING against the balcony in the breeze, he looks resigned. A GUST of wind almost tips him forward. He takes a breath, seems to decide he’s ready. He raises arms as if to swan dive. And then suddenly, he catches a glimpse of the beaver pup on his left hand. He eyes it as if he’d forgotten all abo it. He brings it close. They stare one another down. As he stares, he starts to tip forward, about to fall, bu the last moment, he overcorrects and instead tips backwar toward the room. He falls over the chair and through the open door, CRASHI into the dresser before falling backward onto the ground. A quiet beat until we notice that the shower rod has gott wrapped around the TV and is slowly pulling it toward the edge of the dresser, just above the seemingly unconscious Walter. A beat, and then the TV tips off, landing flat on Walter’ head with a MEATY THUD. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith, Porter, and Henry eat at the table. The awkward indicates this is not a regular thing.  13.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Don’t get me wrong, I’m glad you kicked him out. But the whole eating at the table in response to family drama thing? I mean, how long do you see us keeping this up?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. How about until we start treating one another with some respect? And asking each other about our day. And you two start Saying yes ma’am and no ma’am. And helping with the dishes. And-

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Maybe I should get a paper route too. A long beat then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith, Henry, and Porter sit with their dinner in thei laps watching The Daily Show. Only Jon Stewart speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter blinks awake on the floor. The TV is flat against face, iiterally sitting on his head. Between it and the carpet his field of vision is narrow. Suddenly, he raises his left arm so the beaver puppet is he can see. A long beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Hello, mate. When The Beaver speaks, we recognize the crisp accent fro the narration. Walter’s lips still move, so there’s no confusion about w the sound actually comes from, but for a hand puppet, The Beaver is strangely animated. When Walter speaks, it’s in his own tired, groggy voice, a spite one of them being a puppet, they seem to be having a real back and forth conversation.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. Look at you. Stone drunk and flattened by a television. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Quite an obituary you’re working out for yourself, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is, Walter? You don’t know when to give up. Chicken Soup, Seven Habits, How To Win Friends. Which one has the chapter about dropping a TV on your ead?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Please, just let me rest.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Library for losers, that’s what you've got mate. Books, pills, promises, resolutions. You were ugging Alan Thicke for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I’m sick.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Now on that we agree. The question is, do you want to get better?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Of course, but-

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I know, you're depressed. Lethargic. Anhedonia. Family can’t even stand you anymore and yet you can’t seem to snap out of it, yeah? A beat. Walter nods slightly despite the TV on his head.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: You're going about it all wron mate. These books and pills an shit, they’re cotton candy - You get a little Sugar rush and then, hello, you realize you’re still the same stupid fuck who tries to hug televisions and hang himself from shower rods. Your problem is you've seen too many ho} home improvement shows. You thin ou knock out a wall, change the rapes, everything will be back in order. Doesn’t wor! that way. This thing, it’s like back hair. You cut it, it just grows back thicker. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want things to change, really change, you got to nuke it. Forget home repairs, Walter. If you want to get anywhere you! ve got_to blow up the whole goddamned building.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to do that.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, I do Walter. I do. And I can help you if you let me.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I... yes... please.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: It’s not going to be easy You understand? You have to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yes. Please. Just, just... blow it up. Blow it up. Walter is starting to WEEP again.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Come on now, stay with me. You can’t just toss a bunch of dynamite and run. We gotta bring everything down clean so when we’re done, we can put something new in its place. You understand? Now, do you still have your laptop, or did you rubbish it? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I’m The Beaver, Walter. I’m here to save your goddamned life. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter is in the stands reading GENETIC PSYCHOLOGY TODAY Norah is practicing with the cheerleaders on the floor. The COACH calls a break. Norah splits from the others, gr her bags and moves up to where Porter is. He closes the magazine. She looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (reading) Genetic Psychology Today?  16. He puts the magazine into his bag.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Bookstore was out of US Weekly. He digs her sample out of his bag. He hands it back. She’ surprised.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You don’t need it anymore? I brought others-—

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m not doing it. She’s stunned.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What? Why? He starts speak, but stops suddenly. He hears something. faint WHISTLE each time he exhales. He mashes at his nose until it goes away, then SNAPS the rubber band on his wrist and continues.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Because that’s an excellent paper. You're an excellent writer. Which means that the only reason for me to do this would be because you can’t be bothered to do it yourself. I’m sure shaking pom poms and being anorexic is a ful schedule, I bet if you pot your mind to it, you can work this in. He stands, gathers his things.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You know, it’s one thing to get by on your looks when it’s all you've got. But for someone like you it’s gust lazy. If you’re stuck for a opic, maybe you should just go with that. Short skirts, nose jobs, and get someone else to do it. Worked for me, kids! He starts to go. Norah looks floored. The Coach yells fro the gym floor.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Norah! Let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Hold on!  17. She SLAMS her bag on the ground, starts pulling out paper She slaps them on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (angry) Does that look lazy to you? Porter stops. Turns. She keeps pulling more, stacking the

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I write 10 page papers in an hour and half for easy A’s. The stack keeps growing, heading for War and Peace territ

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how many times I've tried to write this stupid thing? She throws a last set on top.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s 428 pages of lazy. That’s six months of lazy. That’s 63 different opening jokes, famous uotes, and follow your rainbow inspirational bullshit of lazy! The whole Squad is watching from the floor. Porter is cle uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (starting to tear up) I’ve worked harder and longer on this stupid pointless speech with less to show for it than anythin I’ve ever done in my life. And i ou don’t want to take my money ecause of some insecuri’ based bullshit, then fine. But Son’t you dare call me fucking lazy. She hurls her bag at his feet and heads down the stairs, returning to the wide eyed squad. As she goes...

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Asshole. Porter looks stunned, embarrassed. He eyes the stack of papers by his feet. The faint WHISTLE in his breathing returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith scans the elementary kids again. She reaches the TEACHER at the end of the line. She rolls down her window  18.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. He just blends in. I must have missed him again.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Black already got him.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter?

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Said he sent you a text? Quite a character. That doesn’t sound like...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: You're sure it was Walter? Someone HONKS. The teacher moves on. Meredith checks her phone. Sure enough, there’s a text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith wheels into the driveway, opens the garage door. As it rises she sees Henry, bent over a workbench surroun by wood, sawdust, and tools. When he sees her, he looks up, beaming. He seems like an entirely different kid. As Meredith gets out he runs toward her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mom, mom. You gotta see what we did! Come on! She’s stunned by his excitement. He takes her hand, start pulling.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. As he’s dragging her toward the workbench...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is your father? Henry doesn’t hear her. Instead, he picks up a simple, bu impressive, wooden box. He hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY ,
dialogues.text: You put your memory in it. She looks it over, impressed, confused. It strikes her as little nice to have come from her garage.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Where did this come from?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We made it.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: You and your dad?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Me and The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: The beaver? Just then, Walter steps from the house into the garage, a smile as rare and bright as Henry’s on his face. He seems genuinely excited to see her. But before he speaks, Walter raises his left hand reveali the beaver puppet. The Beaver does the talking.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Hello, love. Was just about to call you. Any idea where Walter stuffed the power sander you gave him two Christmases ago? Meredith is stunned into silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No? No trouble. We’1ll make do. (to Walter) Give her the thing. Walter hands her a 3x5 sized card with a message printed it. He then moves past her and joins Henry at the workben Meredith looks at the card.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (reading) Hello. The person who handed you this card is under the care ofa prescription puppet designed to" looking up at Walter) Walter, what the hell is going on? Walter and Henry begin sanding by hand.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Just some male bonding, love. The boy here practically lemanded a gentlemen’s club, but I won him over with the promise of power tools. Henry LAUGHS. Meredith can’t help but gape at the rare so  20.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I mean, what... She moves closer to Walter, lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? We agreed.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Did Henry show you the box? Kid’s a natural. I thought we’d nail a 2x4 to the wall, call it a shelf, but the boy, he’s tongue and grove this and miter saw that. I think his head might be made out of wood. He KNOCKS on Henry’s head as the boy continues to LAUGH, this time it’s not enough. Meredith wants answers.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter. Seriously. Walter and The Beaver look at one another. The Beaver tur to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Henry mate, why don’t you run inside, see if you_can find that varnish we were talking about. Henry drops his sandpaper and takes off like a shot. Walt and The Beaver turn to Meredith.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you read the card?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Yes, but-

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Read the card. She raises the card again. a MEREDITH ai ru in readin: weil? The person who Banded ou this card is under the care ofa prescription puppet designed to elp create a psychological distance between himself and the negative aspects of his personality. Please, treat him as you normally would, but address yourself to the puppet until such time as it is no wit necessary. Failure to do so wil eopardize his hard won therapeutic gains. Thank you.  21. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of joke?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Hardly, love it’s-

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Will you stop with the puppet! Walter looks at The Beaver. The Beaver nods. Walter takes breath, lowers the puppet. His voice is much closer to th tired monotone we heard earlier.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Happy?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: No, Walter. I’m very confused.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Meredith, this is a breakthrough. He says that if I stick with it we can knock down-

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Who says? A long beat as Walter thinks about this one. He looks to Beaver for guidance. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Dr. Macy.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Dr. Macy? I thought you quit seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I went back.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: So this is some kind of... program? Walter raises The Beaver again.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I'll field that one. The answer is yes, Meredith, that’s exactly what it is. I know it seems radical, but that’s because it has to be. In cases like Walter’s, cases where all else has failed, it’s proven quite effective. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But for it to work, he’s got to really commit to cleaning Earn and you house and starting over, ou could g° a long way toward faci litatin is progress if you could just work with him on this. Meredith thinks on this for a second. She looks past The Beaver and right at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: And he really thinks this will work? Walter slides The Beaver back into her eye line.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Absolutely. It’s very big in Sweden. She’s about to say more when Henry comes back from inside

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can’t find it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Not a problem, mate. What you say we get this mess cleaned up? We’l1 worry with the varnish next time.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You’re not leaving are you? THE BEAVER ; Don’t worry, I’1l come round this weekend, we'll finish it up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No, you have to stay for dinner. Mom, let him stay for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: That’s all right mate, I’1l- Meredith looks at Henry’s pleading expression.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: It's okay. You... it’s okay. For dinner. Henry CHEERS. Meredith is still stunned by his demeanor. Walter turns to her. He looks like he wants to say someth but can’t. He just nods, then turns The Beaver to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Right then. Let’s clean up the garage so we can make a mess in the itchen, yeah?  23.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Walter joins Henry as Meredith stares, unsure whose transformation to be more shocked by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter enters, reading from the giant stack of papers tha Norah threw in front of him. He stops. He hears LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter steps in to see Walter using The Beaver to toss a salad, grabbing fistfuls in its jaws with little GROWLS. Henry and Meredith LAUGH at this as they cook.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What - the - fuck. They all look up. Meredith stops jaughing. Before she can anything Walter turns The Beaver toward Porter.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Ah, there he is. Walter moves as if he might hug Porter. Porter recoils, b when Walter gets close, he simply hands over one of his cards.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were afraid we'd have to start without you. Porter reads the card silently. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: This a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: No, son, it’s a fresh start. Porter gapes at The Beaver for a moment, then looks past

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Have you completely lost your mind?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, I know it looks a little-

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you, nut job. I’m asking mom. Meredith starts to say something but Porter cuts her off.  24.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It takes you ou to finally get rid of him an ou let him come back the next night with a talking et eat) I knew you were weak, but Christ.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Porter- But he’s already walked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is on the Daily Show again. NEW ANGLE reveals that Porter is the only one eating in f of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, Henry, and Meredith are at the table. As they eat Meredith is clearly still smarting from Porter's words. She focuses on the memory box which sits just in front of plate. As she handles it, she tries to put on a smile aga

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you guys made this. You never, I mean Walter never... I’m sorry I’m not clear on how I’m supposed to... address you.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: You're doing fine, love.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I mean, the tools were always on your Christmas lists, but rT just assumed it was a_hobby you’d never actually start. I had no idea you knew how to... She indicates the box.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He’s a beaver, mom, that’s what they do.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Spot on, mate. Walter holds The Beaver towards Henry. He exchanges a hig five with The Beaver’s tiny paw.  25.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But xo know, Walter wasn’t half bad himself at one time.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Who taught him?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose he taught himself. He was about your age, yeah? Cub scouts. He and his pop were supposed to make a race car for a contest. Only his pop wasn’t around, so he had to do it himself.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where was his dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter hears this question and MUTES the TV. He looks tow the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith gives Walter a look. Walter absent 1 drags lines through his food with his for he thinks. ie hear a faint WHISTLE in his breaths like th sound Porter <aisciplined himself for making earlier. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: He was in an accident. Passed away.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You mean grandpa? From the graveyard?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Right-o. Anyway, Walter had grandpa’s tools, but not a clue how to use them. Every time he hammered or sawed or chiselled on his block of wood it just got uglier and uglier. the time he was done it Teoked ike he’d taken something a dog had chewed up and screwed wheels on it. Henry LAUGHS. Meredith is listening, not touching her foo

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now all these other kids’ cars, the ones they'd built with their dads, they were things of beauty. And then here was Walter’s, aerodynamic as a billboard, ugly as sin. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So_you know what the other kid’s called it? Henry shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Turd. Henry loves it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you’d seen it, you’d think that was generous. Funny part is, when they actually got down to racing, The Turd could not be beat. All those sanded and shiny opponents, The Turd left them in the dust. Won the whole contest, that little mess.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Sweet.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, the other kids didn’t think so. They teased him about it endlessly. Turd Master, that was his new name. Suddenly this resonates with Henry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Got some books and some wood, and he taught himself all there was to know about those tools. How to make things precise, neat, clean, smooth. Worked until he was better than most of the other kids’ fathers. And when the next year’s contest came he turned in a car that looked like it belonged in a bloody museum.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Did he win?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Didn’t even race. See, by then it didn’t matter how good his car looked. All the other kids saw was that it was Walter’s. They called it The Turd II. (beat) So he told them to piss off and took it home. We see Porter listening gtoselys unconsciously drawing li lines in his food just like Walter  27.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: That sucks.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Indeed, mate. Indeed. But Walter doesn’t have to worry about those kinds of things anymore. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Because he’s got me. Walter goes back to eating. Meredith watches Henry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Dad, can we make a turd?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Anytime, mate. Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Let’s do it tomorrow. INT. HENRY’S ROOM Walter tucks Henry in. He kisses him on each cheek, one w his lips, one with The Beaver’s.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Good night, Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Good night, mate. Walter flips out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter joins Meredith. They move down to Porter’s doorway

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Porter, your dad’s leaving. You want to say goodbye? Porter gets up from his desk, walks toward the doorway li he might say something. Instead, he SLAMS the door in the faces. Loud MUSIC quickly follows from within. Meredith moves to reopen it, but Walter grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: He’s a teenager, love. We’d only have to worry if he liked us.  28. She lowers her arm. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Do you have far to go? I mean, you can stay on the couch if you need to.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: That’s all right. The hotel is actually closer to the office. We've got a big day tomorrow. He gives her a quick kiss on the cheek and starts down th stairs. A moment before something occurs to her. She steps to the of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to go to work like this?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: (without looking back) Bright and early, love, bright and ear She watches him go, suddenly concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter is walking around on his cell, Norah’s pages in ha

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (filter) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Norah. It’s Porter. Listen, about what I said earlier-

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Are you going to help me or not?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Well... I’ve been reading your stuff, and I think maybe if we talked more about what you're trying to say-

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Fine. Come by after school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Um- She hangs up. Porter puts the phone down. He looks satisf mildly upbeat.  29. Then he looks out his window and sees Walter getting in h car. Walter looks up, sees Porter, and raises The Beaver wave goodbye. And like that, Porter goes south. He sits on his bed to t and finds himself instinctively y massaging his eyebrows saw before. The faint WHISTLE in his breaths returns. He catches himself doing these things and, in a flash of frustration, pounds on his head with his fists. Unsatisfied, he pulls _a poster from the wall revealing t large dent we saw earlier and begins POUNDING his head in the drywall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the outside of Porter’s wall where his blows for cracks in the stucco. With each hit, chips fall away unti finally hear a heavy THUD followed by SILENCE. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is jogging; Pull back to reveal that he’s holding beaver in front of him as he does, almost a hood ornament

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter showers. He soaps himself and The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands in a towel BLOW DRYING The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER PRESSES a suit. The Beaver guides the iron. WALTER STRAIGHTENS his tie. WALTER COMBS The Beaver’s fur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter regards himself and The Beaver in the mirror. He l like a Brooks Brothers model... with a beaver on his hand He stares at The Beaver for a long beat. He looks nervous Finally...  30.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Trust me, mate. Today will be different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot shows rows of cubes. No one’s here yet. There small card in the center of each desk. CLOSE ON a single desk. The card is the same therapeutic caution card Walter gave to Meredith and Porter. NEW ANGLE inside of a pair of cubes, the card in the cent of the desks. NEW ANGLE inside of an office. The same situation. NEW ANGLE as EMPLOYEES begin to stream in. A couple get t their desks. They pick up the card. They look at one anot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As people stream in, we see a large sign on the front doo It reads: ALL HANDS MEETING - CAFETERIA 9AM - NO EXCEPTIO They MURMUR about this as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMPLOYEES take seats and TALK, many of them holding and discussing the cards. THE VP walks in, also carrying a card. A SKEPTICAL MAN gr him.

dialogues.speaker: SKEPTICAL MAN
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? The VP looks as confused as everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: I... have no idea. — SKEPTICAL MAN. This is layoffs, isn’t it? Suddenly the room goes QUIET as everyone looks at The VP his answer. Then, from the front of the room...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: No one’s getting laid off.  31. All the heads whip around to find Walter standing before them, The Beaver raised and held forward.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get rid of you all and I’ve no one to boss around, yeah? Thundering SILENCE. ANGLE ON Walter and The Beaver. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good Morning. I assume you all got the cards informing you of the new arrangements here, but if not, allow me to briefly explain. As you know Walter Black ascended to CEO here nearly two years ago, not through any particular skill or merit, but because the hooker our founder took to dinner did not know the Heimlich maneuver. It was a_ job Walter was ill prepared to handle, and his deteriorating mental health since then has led to lapses in focus, judgement, and eight straight losing quarters that leave us facing impending bankruptcy. That is why, as of now, he is resigning. Quiet MURMURING.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And putting me in charge. Now the MURMURS become LOUD CHATTER and DISMAY. ANGLE ON The VP who takes a chair, bewildered. ANGLE ON Walter and The Beaver. Walter motions for quiet.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five minutes, mates, then you may tear me to shreds if you like. A modicum of SILENCE returns.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As my first order of business as CEO I want to take this opportunity to announce some significant reforms and goal realignments. GROANS .

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First, I am rolling back the cumbersome approva rocess instituted (ORE a4 predecessor.  32.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The truth is, he had no idea what he was doing and he reacted to his fear by attempting to micromanage people and projects that were outside his area of expertise. As of this moment I am ceding control of all individual projects back to the teams themselves. No more endless meetings and waiting for the CEO's blessing. You will all be free and entrusted to do the jobs you were hired to do. This is the first thing they’ve heard that sounds good. Still, they’re highly dubious of the source.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Second, we have lacked anything resembling a strategic plan as Walter has pursued and abandoned countless ill conceived new product lines and_handicapped them b alternately inter tering in their development and sleeping for large portions of the day. As of this moment, we will cease work on all but our two core lines, Action Jack and Princess Stephanie. These are high value properties that have grown stale through mismanagement and neglect - We will revamp and revitalize them, and then we will relaunch them at the International Game and Toy Manufacturers Expo in six weeks. Significant GRUMBLING.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's a bloody difficult timeline, but I’ve prepared a schedule that you'll find in your email when you return to your desks which demonstrates how, by focusing on these two lines éxelusively and eliminating bureaucratic delays, it is indeed achievable. It has to be. The bottom line is that the expo provides the only near term opportunity for the significant boost in orders that we require to right our ship. A beat as he lets them digest this.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: pastly, you're all highly intelligent people, so I can imagine that you have a healthy degree of skepticism regarding my ability to lead under these... circumstances.  33. Significant AGREEMENT.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I’m offering you the following deal. You will give me two weeks. At the end of that time anyone who goes not see significant improvement and chooses to resign 1 receive eight full months Severance and a glowing letter of recommendation. No questions asked, no exceptions. ANGLE ON the crowd. This is quite an offer. ANGLE ON Walter and The Beaver. He waits for quiet. Then.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Understand one thing my friends. This will become a great place to work again. You have my word on that. From the back...

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: And, who exactly are you supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Bollocks. Did I forget to introduce myself? Apologies. CLOSE ON Walter’s lips. He subtly bites the right corner his lower one before he says...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may simply call me The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Porter's iips: He’s biting his lower one exactly like Walter as he takes in the room. It’s like a Siehotg case. Awards, medals, ribbons, plaque everywhere, although for a head cheerleader, there’s noth particularly feminine: no posters, no pink, etc.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (regarding the walls) This is... impressive. She shrugs it off. Her attitude is all business.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: So, what do you need to know?  34.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Right. I guess the first thing we have to figure out is what you want to say. Well, that’ nS Aainda the problem. I have no idea. I mean, I’ve been on this track, you know, school, sports, Stanford for like, ever. I haven't really had to think about what’s next, it’s just been... obvious. So, I don’t really know what I’m supposed to say to people who don’t have all that figured out yet.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I see. So, your basic overachiever needs help addressing the little people speech - Have a nice summer, luck in community college. tuff like that?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You think you’ve got me all figured out, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (looking, around) I’m piecing it together.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What I’m trying to say is that good grades haven't suddenly given me this brilliant insight into what everyone should do with their lives. If anything it’s the opposite. I mean, when they were expelling me from junior high no one was asking for my advice, but get a few A’s and now I’m supposed to have all the answers?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I must have misheard you. It sounded like you said expelled.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: That surprises you?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Depends on what it was for. If it had anything to do with Freeing Tibet, then no, it doesn’t surprise me at all.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: How about graffiti?  35.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Let me guess: Stanford Rules in big block letters.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: More of an unauthorized mural. I was going through an ‘angry rebel artist’ phase.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Sorry. Not possible. Does not compute.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it’s in my file. So, see, you don’t know everything.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: And where’s all this angry rebel artist stuff now?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It was a long time ago. Why?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Why? Because when the student body president, chess club champion, cheerleader, valedictorian tells you that she used to make defiant Masterpieces you kind of want to see one. She just looks at him, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You still have something don’t you? Come on. Just one look and_I’1l write you a speech you could run for president with. Please. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: How about if you just agree to stop being an ass?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Be easier to get you elected. She starts to turn away.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, roxas okay. I'll be good. (hand on his heart) Promise.  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah and Porter stand at the bedroom door next to her ow In addition to the knob, there’s a padlocked latch. She dials in the combination. CLICK. As she opens the doo

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: We have to be quick. Porter suddenly isn’t sure what he’s getting into. INT. NORAH'S BROTHER’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS They step in to find a bedroom eerily similar to Norah’s Trophies, awards, ribbons, plaques. They aren’t carbon copies, but there’s a strong feeling of deja vu. Porter takes this in, confused.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Whose room is this?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Used to be my brother’s. She motions toward the one thing that makes this room distinctly different from hers: a painting on the far wal

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, there you go. Porter looks it over. It’s not bad. Kind of frenzied. Impressionistic. Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You did this?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, it’s very funny. So now you've seen it. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: No, I mean, it’s... really good. Really. She’s not sure how to take this.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Well... thanks. He goes back to looking at the painting. A beat, then she goes to the closet, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, I never understood why he hung that one.  37. She pulls out several canvases, settles on one. She holds up.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was always my favorite. Porter steps over. The style is similar, but it’s brighte more aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Wow. He starts to thumb through the others.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are great. Where did you learn to do this?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I didn’t. I mean, I wasn’t serious about it or anything. It was just a phase. You know, my brother was Mr. All American so I went out of my way to be all artsy and rebellious. It was stupid. She starts to put the paintings away.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Why do you keep them in here?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I don’t. I didn’t keep any o these. I threw them out, The whole thing was just to be weird and piss off my parents . Brian, he’s the one who pulled them out of the trash.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: He must have really liked them. She closes the closet.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know about that. I mean, he was always encouraging me, telling me how w great I_was, how talented I was, it felt like a big mind game, you know? Like he’d read some psycho ogy book that told him that he pretended to like them I'd give it up. She walks back to the painting on the wall.  38.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, my parents, they were always trying to get me to quit, especially after I started painting walls instead of canvases, and Brian, he was always so concerned about them, telling me how my getting into trouble was tearing them up and stuff. So I always figured this was just his hyper gmart way of trying to get me in ine. Porter hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Where’s your brother now? Norah looks at him as if the question surprises her, as i she thought it was something he already knew. A beat. She walks to the corner and grabs the edge of a large des Suddenly, she HEAVES and it GRINDS away from the wall. She stares at the floor in the corner. Porter steps over. There, painted onto the wood floor is the beginnings of w might be a mural.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I_ got the idea from this magazine. Floor murals. It was sort of my way of making him admit that he didn’t really like my stuff, that he was just_trying to manipulate me. It was like, you like my shit, well, here you go... She indicates the floor. Porter nods, but his face says h doesn’t quite get it.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I was grounded, everybody was gone. And then he came home. Caught me. He didn’t really get mad. He just looked at it for a long time and then he walked out. So I’m following him screaming, ‘Don’t you like it? Aren’t I talented? Aren’t I great?’ But he won’t say anything. He just goes straight to his car, this is like 10 o'clock at night, and as he’s backing out he smiles and shakes his head and then, really calmly, he says ‘Don’t worry - We'll get it up before they get home.’ A long beat as she stares at the beginnings of the painti mesmerized. When she speaks, her voice is on the edge of cracking.  39.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The weird thing was, there was no rain, no ice, no drunk driver. I mean, the car didn’t even look that bad. It looked like something you could have walked away from. A beat, then she pushes the desk back into the corner.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: When we went to get his car there was all this floor fixing stuff in the back. Strippers, sanders, varnish. I remember my parents and I, we all stared at it, and I kept waiting for them to say something, to ask me something. I wanted them to. But they didn’t. They didn’t say a word. And then the next time I came in here - (she pats the desk) - this had been pushed into the corner. I mean, it’s not like they couldn’t figure out what happened. I guess they just felt like words weren’t going to change it. Porter starts to say something when suddenly NORAH’S MOTH appears in the doorway. NORAH’S MOM What are you doing in here? She sounds more hurt than angry. Norah doesn’t miss a bea When she answers the emotional waver is replaced with upb confidence.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I was just showing Porter some of Brian’sS awards. He’s on the math team with me. Norah’s mom steps in. NORAH’S MOM Oh. Did you know Brian?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Um, no, ma’am. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH'S MOM
dialogues.text: Oh. An awkward silence. They’re all looking at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Well, we've got some studying to oO.  40. Norah pushes Porter towards the door. Her mom doesn’t say anything. At the door Norah looks back. Her mom is still just staring at the desk, transfixed. Norah turns to Porter.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: quiet) You should go. I’m sorry. Do you have enough to work with?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I'll figure it out. Norah nods and turns back toward her mom.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (brightly) Hey mom, do you know where that olarship xotice is? They wanted a picture and bio, but I don’t have the address. As Porter exits, Norah’s mom finally looks up, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the right half of the screen, Porter gets into his car sits behind the wheel. On the left half of the screen, Walter sits behind his de so that the tableaus almost match CLOSE ON both their faces as they fall into what almost l like identical pensive trances. They each begin to tap th chins with their index fingers.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a picture of Walter Black, a hopelessly depressed individual. Slowly match pull backs on both until The Beaver becomes visible in Walter’s frame.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who becomes a beaver. Then, suddenly, they both seem to wake at the same moment When Porter realizes what he’s been doing, he SNAPS the rubber band on his wrist and starts his car. When Walter gets with it, he turns to The Beaver, nods. NEW ANGLE shows full screen on Walter’s office and whips around to reveal THE VP and others sitting across the des  41. They close their notepads and seem satisfied. The VP look Walter, nods back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Employees are working, hustling.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At work his reforms foster a fresh level of focus and energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits at a table with other employees. Walter takes a bite of his sandwich, then takes another u The Beaver. They chew in unison though The Beaver’s bite simply falls in pieces onto the table. The employees look at one another with uncertain expressi

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And for every person who points out that_he’s begun to feed lunch to his left hand there’s another to remind them that production has already increased by 35%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Employees are gathered around the table. At the head, onl The Beaver is visible, talking. The camera sinks down to reveal Walter under the table. THE BEAVER (V.O. For every person who worries that he’s begun to_conduct meetings from under the table, there’s another to point out that he’s come up with an exciting scenario for the Action Jack line. At the end of those first two weeks, not one person resigns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith pulls up outside the school. This time when Henr opens the front door, several other KIDS open the rear do They all get in together, TALKING, LAUGHING.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and the other kids are all working on various wood projects.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Things are different at home too. Suddenly, Walter enters with The Beaver. The kids drop wh they're doing | and flock to him. He acknowledges them al goes out of his way to lavish attention on a smiling Henr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter reads Norah’s papers. He thinks. Starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids working around him, Walter, eyes his project, thinks continues working. The Beaver grips the hammer in his mou THE BEAVER (V.O. sd And eventually, what Scme strange becomes common. Pull back to reveal that they’re working on a miniature d for The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, Meredith, and Walter eat at the table. They’re smiling, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What seemed impossible becomes real. Porter takes a plate, but stops in the doorway, watching Walter put food in The Beaver’s mouth. Disgusted, he leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter’s food sits on his desk, untouched. Instead, he’s his bed POUNDING his head into the dent. He takes a moment, looks into the hole. He can see cracks the wall going all the way out. He seems inspired by this presses on.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Porter subbing the knot on his head when HECTOR walks up, excited. He hands Porter a newspaper clipping. headline: LOCAL MINORITY WINS ESSAY SCHOLARSHIP. Hector holds out his fist for a bump. Porter complies, bu he’s already distracted.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Until it becomes hard to remember how things were before. Norah and the cheer squad come by though now she’s the on one not in uniform. He smiles. e smiles. The squad GIGGLE Porter opens his locker as Hector is still going on. His phone goes off. He gets a text: ANOREXIA CROWD THINKS

dialogues.speaker: CUTE BUT NEED TO DROP FEW LBS
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter works with a WOMAN at her machine. She holds fabri to The Beaver, takes measurements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On tor of Walter’s desk, there’s now an identical, smalle desk for The Beaver. The way it’s set up, you can’t see Walter’s arm. Just two CEO’s at identical desks and now in identical suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Meredith are drinking wine by candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Walter hasn't just made a fresh start with himself- The Beaver is talking. She’s LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - but with the people he loves. A long quiet beat. She smiles. Hold on her smile, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Meredith are Kissing - The Beaver undoes the buttons on her blouse. She looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When they kiss it’s like the first time. Like it’s all brand new. CLOSE ON her face as Walter kisses her neck and then move down. She looks aroused. Then surprised. Then she closes eyes, slams a pillow over her face and SCREAMS into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith lays in bed looking toward the bathroom. NEW ANGLE shows Walter’s silhouette in the shower. He soa his own head, then the Beaver’s, as we’ve seen before.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Like they’re different people all together. ANGLE ON Meredith, her smile cracking into a look of mild concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Employees around the table. The Beaver talking. They all NEW ANGLE reveals conference call equipment on the table.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At work, they decide to schedule his meetings with outsiders as conference calls. It isn’t that they aren’t behind him, they just aren’t sure they can explain what they're seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith opens the door revealing PARENTS of one of the k They start to come in, but she steps in front of them, closing the door a fraction. She holds up a finger.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Meredith starts to feel the same way. Meredith summons one of the kids who’s playing with The Beaver in the background. When he gets to the door she op up just enough to let him out.  45. Off the Parents confused expression...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry works hard as the other kids play.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Even Henry begins to worry her. His interest in woodwork starts to seem more and more like an obsession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry continues working hard, now all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to the original coffee table, is a second, identical coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous bird house is swarmed by birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith looks at a long list of various types of wood.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His birthday wishlist contains nothing but wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter lays in bed, face down. Meredith rolls over, blink awake. She finds herself staring into the large, wide ope plastic eyes of The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith is surrounded by the Soccer Moms.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Have any of you ever tried... role playing?

dialogues.speaker: SOCCER MOM 1
dialogues.text: Jim tried to dress me up like a secretary once. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SOCCER MOM 1, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then he just started screwing his real secretary and I got the house. ANN, the Alpha mom in the bunch weighs in. ANN ; ; It’s not healthy. Dressing up like a cheerleader doesn’t solve anything, it just covers up the fact that something is seriously wrong underneath. No one wants to follow that. Ann looks at Meredith.

dialogues.speaker: ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why? Are you seeing someone? All the heads turn.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Well... actually, Walter and I have been... working on things. The other ladies look surprised. Ann looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: And how’s that affecting the kids?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Well, Henry’s doing great. Mostly. And Porter, I don’t know. He’s a teenager. The other ladies nod in understanding.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: So you and Walter, you’re trying some sort of role playing therapy?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Well, mostly Walter.

dialogues.speaker: SOCCER MOM 2
dialogues.text: And is it better... I mean... you know, in bed.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Well... yeah. I mean, that’s good, but it’s not really about that. I don’t know. This intrigues the others, but Ann cuts them off.

dialogues.speaker: ANN
dialogues.text: Well, just be careful. People don’t put on a disguise unless they've got something to hide. This seems to land for Meredith. She sips her drink.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith is lying next to Walter, The Beaver on the pillo between them.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Did you talk to Dr. Macy today?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Indeed. Says we're coming along brilliantly.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: That’s great. Did he give you any sort of, you know, like a timeline? For when the treatment might be over? Walter rolls away toward his night stand and grabs a smal eye shield. He places it over The Beaver’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Nothing specific.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: But do you think, like a week? A month? He flips out the light. In the dark.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: It's a process, love. When the time is right, we'll know. Walter flips over, burying his face in the pillow. Meredi is left staring at The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith wakes with a start. She hears soft BANGING. She out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith opens the door to the garage revealing Henry, working away on a project. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith returns, flips on the light.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter. Walter, wake up. Walter rouses, pulling the mask off The Beaver’s eyes.  48.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong, love?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: You need to talk to Henry. He's down in the garage again.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, tell him to come to bed.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I’ve told him, Walter. I tell him everyday. He pays no attention to me. He needs to hear it from, you know... (indicating The Beaver) you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter comes out in his pajamas, walks over to Henry, loo over his shoulder. Henry looks up at Walter and The Beave

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You couldn’t sleep either?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Actually, mate, I was sleeping quite well. You know you can’t be out here this late.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I just had this idea. It’s gonna be really great.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, let’s have it be great in the morning, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: dust ten more minutes, please. Just let me finish this last set of cuts. The Beaver considers this.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I let you have ten more minutes, you have to promise, no more working when your mother’s asked you, not to. Not at night. Not uring breakfast. No bringing your tools to the dentist. Agreed? Walter puts forward The Beaver’s paw. Henry shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Agreed.  49. Walter starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you stay? I like working with you around. Walter stops.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Sure. Henry smiles, goes back to work. Walter watches him for a moment. He turns to a table and grabs his own piece of wo Walter and The Beaver begin to noodle on the wood. A chip here, chisel there.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Will you talk to me? I like it when you talk.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: What would you like to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter. Just talk. Walter continues to work away. THE BEAVER, ; Very well. You’re quite easily entertained, aren’t you? Suddenly Walter freezes. He looks at Henry - There might well be a giant light bulb over Walter's head. Walter turns back to his block of wood with a feverish energy. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You’re not talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter comes racing into the room, heads straight for the closet. Meredith sits up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Did you talk to him? Walter comes out of the closet in the midst of changing i a suit. He heads into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walter?  50.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. Yes. We had a good chat. He'll stick to the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Walter comes out, mostly dressed, a tie loosely slung aro his neck. He wrestles into some Shoes.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I’ve had a breakthrough, love. I’ve got to get to work.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Not a moment to spare. He starts for the door, then pauses. He comes back to bed kiss her goodbye. But this time Walter stands back and only kisses her chee with The Beaver. And then he’s gone. Meredith looks after him with heavy concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter works feverishly at a workstation. The VP is the f one in. He spots Walter.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Sir? You’re in early. Walter looks up. He raises The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Ah! Just the man I was hoping to see. Come over, mate. We're goin to need to get going on this Seight away. The VP takes a seat next to Walter. Walter hands him the piece of wood he was working on. It’s been roughed out in the crude likeness of a beaver. The VP looks at it. He’s not sure what it means.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: It's... a beaver?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: It’s the future. It only occurred to me last night that I’ve been focus group testing it for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is what we’ve been looking for. The VP looks at the crude block again.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: This? The Beaver directs his attention to the monitor. ANGLE ON the monitor where we see various schematics for beaver toy with a toolkit.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: It's a talking beaver woodworking set. You get the basic tools, a block of wood, and a talking beaver to work along side you. The VP looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should see the kids mate. They go crazy for the stuff. Theyre into the video games and cell hones sure, but you give them a ammer, a saw and a block of wood, I'm telling ou, it comes natural. And as for the beaver, I don’t want to brag, but there’s not a one of them who wouldn’t take me home if they could.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: So... you’re talking about a new product line? For what, Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Christmas? I’m talking about right now. Today. This morning.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: But that’s impossible. You said yourself, the only way we can get the new Jack and Stephanie lines ready is by-

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Forget Jack and Stephanie. This is it, right here.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: But sir-

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Action Jack and Princess Stephanie can only hope to take us where we've been. This has the potential to open up a whole new world of opportunities. I’m as sure of it as I’ve ever been of anything.  52. The VP looks at The Beaver, then back at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: I guess there could be an ancillary market in more tools. Maybe precut lumber pieces. Sort of like Lego kits, but made of wood and you work them into shape on your own. Walter looks excited. The Beaver musses The VP’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Exactly! Now you’re talking!

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: But this would mean... I mean, if we could even get one ready, this is all we'd have for the expo.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: This is all we’ll need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beaver is at the head of the table sitting behind his little desk, but this time it’s The VP who does the talki He points to a cleaned up version of the beaver kit schem and a chart.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Replicating The Beaver as a core item along with endless project kits would seem to have great appeal and taking a conservative view of the Lego model’s numbers, we're talking about an exponential return. The staff looks around. They’re intrigued, but unsure.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: It’s risky, no doubt, and if we come up short with the beaver we go to_ the expo empty handed, which, in all_likelihood, would result in’a failure to remain solvent. No one likes this. The Beaver speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Friends, this is our future. Do we want to continue doing the things that have previously resulted in our minor success and hope that they’re enough to survive, or do we break with ‘the past and embrace something new, something different, something better. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The question is not whether or not this can work, the question is whether or not we’re bold enough to take it on. Everyone looks around, thinking, considering, deciding. A long beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINTERS SPEW copies of the beaver schematics. MONITORS SHOW diagrams of the toolbox being manipulated. WORKERS MEASURE The Beaver himself to get dimensions. The Beaver nods toward The VP. THE VP nods back and then looks around as people hustle about. He looks proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter is sitting across from a panic stricken Hector.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What the fuck do I always say Hector? Read it before you turn it in. It was about your own family for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I just figured since it was personal there couldn’t be no test questions on it. It’s your fault. If it hadn’t been so good it won that award, wouldn’t be no big ea

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Your own dad turned you in?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
