dialogues.text: My grandma, she was so proud, she was talking to me about all this stuff you wrote, stuff about her and my grandad, back in the war, and then all of a sudden she could just tell I didn’t know nothing about what she was saying. And she just starts crying. So my dad, he call the principa said he don’t want me to get the’ scholarship. Wants it to go to someone who really respects their family history.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Look, Hector, this is your problem, you understand. My name stays out of it.  54.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Man, they’re already talking about expulsion if I don’t tell them where it came from.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Tell them you bought it off the internet.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: It’s a personal essay about my family. You can’t just get those on the internet. Porter considers this for a second.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Okay. I’11 make a dummy website. Paper writing for hire. You give them the web address, tell them you sent your money in, got your paper back, that’s all you know. They can look all they want, it won’t come back to me.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: I don’t know man. I feel like shit as it is. If you’d seen my grandma-

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Look! I’m sorry you didn’t read our own essay, ut giving me me up isn’t going to change tha trusted you and you broke the rules, so I’m counting on you to do the right thing here. Porter sees Norah come in.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta go. I’1ll send you the fake site address by tomorrow. Okay? Porter stands to leave. Hector doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. Porter moves quickly over to Norah. She smiles as he near

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Hey.  55.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Was your coach upset?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: He just told me not to miss anymore workouts. He thinks you’re a bad influence.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I told you you didn’t have to give me a ride.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. I wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: So... um, are you busy tonight?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Are you about to ask me out?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. My plan was to get a feel for the situation. If it seemed like you weren’t into it, I was just going to say that I had worked up a beginning for the speech and that we should g together and make sure you Sef ink I’m on the right track.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: And if it seemed like I was into it?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Actually, just kind of discounted that possibi ity. I think I was going to casually ask you if you wanted to do something withou making it sound like I'd been up all night planning something elaborate.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Have you been planning something elaborate?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I have like maps and stuff. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You can pick me up at 7. I have to be home ¥ 12. And I do want to see what you have of the speech.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (surprised Um..okay. It’s a date.  56. Coyly, as she goes...

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: We'll see. INT. WALTER’S BATHROOM/ PORTER’S BATHROOM - INTERCUT QUICK CUTS of Walter and Porter getting ready. THEY BOTH carefully comb their hair. PORTER SELECTS from several T shirts. WALTER BUTTONS a very nice shirt. PORTER PULLS on jeans. WALTER SLIDES into very nice pants. PORTER CHECKS his face in the mirror, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (to himself) Please, don’t fuck this up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter checks the Beaver in the mirror, shows its big gri He turns The Beaver towards himself.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Just let me lead, we’1ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter emerges from the bathroom pulling on a sharp suit jacket.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Almost ready, love? Reservations are for eight and I still need to slip on my suit. Meredith emerges from the sloset in a stunning dress.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, woman. Look at you. She grins, walks toward him.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: You look pretty good yourself.  57.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Oh, you haven’t seen anything yet. The girls whipped up something special for me. We’re talking full on tux, love. Just give me a minute to pop it on and we’re off. Meredith realizes that Walter is talking about dressing T Beaver. Her face loses some spark. A hesitant beat. As he starts for the closet she stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter, come on. I mean, it’s our 20th anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Of course dear. That’s why I thought a tux was appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: No, I mean, maybe this would be a good time to try. you_know, ringing the other Walter back.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, I don’t think that’s a good idea. The doctor said very- Meredith turns serious.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I do not want to celebrate 20 years of marriage with a puppet. I’m sorry, I've been very patient, very supportive. Is it so much to ask that you give me one night? Walter considers this. He SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Compromise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Meredith step in. We see that he still has The Beaver on his hand, but its not dressed, and not held up. When the hostess looks up at bam, Walter looks nervous, unsure. Then, with his own voice.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Black. Party of two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter is driving as Norah reads some pages.  58.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: This is amazing. Really. My parents are going to flip. beat) I don’t deserve credit for something like this. I’m just gonna tell people you wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Trust me, as long as I get a diploma and get out of here, the credit is all yours. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You know, if I was leaving the west coast for Rhode Island I don’t think I’d be in such a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You clearly haven't met my family. It’s gonna be hard enough to make it 10 more weeks without putting my head through a wall.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What do they...beat you?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Yes. With stuffed animals and handmade furniture.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Nothing. He suddenly pulls the car to stop. He backs UP turns so t the car is left facing the street. He turns off the engin

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. Here we are. Norah looks around. It’s not a great part of town. The ro is pot-holed, empty, dark. Thereé’s a freeway on-ramp in distance. Other than urban decay, not much to see.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Well, look, I appreciate your confidence, but usually if you’re going to ‘park’ with a girl, you want to find a view with more stars and less homeless. He twists the rear view mirror so that she can see behind them. It’s the side of an abandoned hospital building.  59.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Still not doing it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah beside him, Porter opens the trunk revealing a nest various spray and regular paints.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (nervous ) Ta-da. Norah just stares at them blankly.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The neighborhood really isn’t as bad as it looks. According to the web there were less that two murders per square mile here last ear. And this place got closed for angerous levels of asbestos, so it’s not like anyone is going to bother us. She’s still just looking at him. He pulls out some of the paint.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The guy in the store was a little suspicious so I had to get some colors that didn’t seem, like, vandalism related. Can you do graffiti in Robin's Egg? A long beat. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Porter, this is sweet and all, but, really, I told you, I wasn’t really into any of this, it was just a stupid thing I did to get attention.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Sure. I_know. It just seemed like you really had talent. I hate to see you give it up just because - Porter suddenly realizes there’s no good way to finish th sentence.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (almost daring him to finish) Just because?  60.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Because, you got in trouble once.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: So this was your elaborate plan? To take me out to vandalize a building that’s empty because it causes cancer?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: It sounds less romantic when you say it that way.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: And what did you think we would paint? Norah Porter 4ever?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What were you starting to paint on your brother’s floor? Norah's face goes cold. A beat, and then she walks away, in the car, closes the door. Porter stands there a moment holding cans of spray paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter slowly opens and then gets into the driver’s side. They sit in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You know, I don’t need you to like, fix me, okay?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I wasn't trying, I swear. I just, I wanted to do something you'd remember.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I think you’d rather I forget this.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Look, I know I’m not exactly yo your t e, so I figured that my be shot was to just try to be really different.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Porter, your best shot is to be yourself

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Now, see, that just shows that you don’t really know me.  61.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I mean, it was a nice thought, I ess, but it’s... too much. You now? Just stop trying so hard. You’re already in. Porter looks up, then over at her. A beat as he digests t

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I am? She nods, then starts to lean in ever so slightly. He hesitates. Is this what it seems like?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (reading his mind) Yes. This is where you kiss me. He nods slightly, moves in, kisses her. They wrap their a around one another. He begins to rub her back. As he does, his right hand drifts up towards her hair, an then, slowly, unconsciously, he begins to spin a lock of around his index finger. Suddenly, his eyes pop wide open and he jerks away as if been shocked.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? What?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: That thing. That thing I just did.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: With your hair! He angrily hits himself in the head a few times. As he oes...

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s new. That’s a new one.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Porter? Porter, you’re kinda freaking me out. Porter puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: That’s 58.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? He looks like he wants to explain, but can’t find the wor  62. Norah is totally lost. Her face says she’s decided this w all a big mistake. She’s about to Say so when her phone rings. She looks at it, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (bright ) Hey mom. Disgusted with himself, Porter gets out of the car, walks away. Norah makes a motion like ‘where are you going’ but he’s gone. She stays on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, we're still studying. Just getting back to the library. Um, okay. I guess. Actually, we might ack early. Yeah. We don’t have as much to go over as I thought. Okay. Yeah, I’11 call you. Love you. Bye. Norah hangs up. She SIGHS. She takes a long beat deciding what she wants to do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah opens her door gets out. When she turns she sees Po standing by the side of the building. In Robin’s Egg he’s written:

dialogues.speaker: FOR AN AWKWARD TIME CALL PORTER BLACK
dialogues.text: She can’t help but smile. She walks toward him. They both stare at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I know you're new at this, but you usually want to avoid using your full name. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: What was that back there? Porter shakes his head. He looks at the rubber band on hi wrist. Toys with it.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: How may little ways do you think two things can be alike before you have to start worrying about the big ones? She has no idea what to say to this. He turns to her.  63.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: This is like, the worst first date ever, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Yes. She takes the spray can out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So far. She walks up and starts to paint out his name.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to cover this up, and then you" re going to buy me something to eat in part of town where no one was murdered this week and then I’1l get back to you. Deal? Porter is about to answer when suddenly a spotlight hits them. They turn to see a police car idling in the street. A lon beat, then... The police car flips on its red and blue lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and Meredith are eating. It’s silent. Awkward. Wal keeps The Beaver in his lap. He looks nervous. The WAITER steps over.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: How is everything? Walter looks at Meredith. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Excellent. Thanks. (beat) You know, now might be a good time for the...

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. The waiter departs. Meredith smiles at Walter. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I was listening to the radio. Apparently it’s supposed to_be really hot this weekend. Well, not really hot, but hot. Above average.  64. Walter nods. They’ve been reduced to talking about the weather.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s work? Are you making the schedule?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It’s good. (beat) Busy. Now Meredith nods. Walter’s face says he’s trying. He doe look depressed. More deer in the headlights. SILENCE. The waiter returns and places a wrapped gift on the table

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Thank you. She pushes it across to Walter.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go ahead. He reaches out to unwrap it, using his free hand and The Beaver. Inside is a memory box, similar to the first one saw, but significantly more ornate.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's very nice. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Henry helped me. Which means, I bought the wood and Henry made it. (beat Look ‘inside. He opens the box. It’s full of old photos. ANGLE ON the photos. They’re all shots Walter and Meredit younger, happier times.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was tooking through some things. I just thought... it’s important to remind ourselves, you know, how it was. How it should be. He flips through. Shots of them smiling, laughing, holdin babies. Shots of them in Halloween costumes, at Christmas parties, on vacation. Him with her on his shoulders. As he looks, Walter starts to tear up and CRY. For a mome it’s just a quiet sentimental WEEP. But it quickly expand into a more hiccupy-breakdown-SOB. Other diners stare.  65.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walter. Walter, it’s okay. Hon, look at me. Walter. But he’s inconsolable. He just keeps staring at the last photo, her on his shoulders, both of them laughing. He’s worked up a solid cry now. Everyone is staring. Suddenly... He raises The Beaver. Just the act of doing so helps him choke back the tears. He lets it take over.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Is this what you want? Is this progress? Christ, woman, he’s ffering from dé ression, not amnesia. You think the problem is that he just doesn’t remember these things? Remembering has nothing to do with it. He can remember what it was like to play little league. That doesn’t mean he can go sign up for a team! The sight of The Beaver has the other diners really locke in. Meredith is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He can’t go back. Don’t you see that? This is all in the past, and dredging it up... we all know "where this leads. We know where Walter oes. You want the rest of your ife to be like tonight? That's Walter. That’s the best he can do. He’s not going back to that. Suddenly she doesn’t care who’s watching.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Her cell phone is RINGING on the table.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: It means we’ve turned over a new leaf. We’ve got a fresh start. We- She’s not planning to answer, but when she sees the name, picks up immediately.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Porter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter and Norah sit in chairs against a wall. She’s CRYI He tries to console her. She jerks away. NEW ANGLE reveals NORAH’S MOM AND DAD marching up to them They stare down at Norah NORAH’S DAD I don’t even know what to say. I'd hoped we were past this sort of thing. He doesn’t sound upset, but numb. But, for Norah, this is worse. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Sir, this is a big misunderstanding. It was completely my—

dialogues.speaker: NORAH'S DAD
dialogues.text: Let's go. Norah gets /BPr walks away with them. Porter keeps watchi hoping she’ll at least look back, but she doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Norah. Norah, I’m sorry. Norah’s mom gives him a glare, but Norah never turns. As Norah's family nears the front, Walter and Meredith co in. Porter can’t hear, but he sees Walter raise The Beave and start talking to the SERGEANT at the front. Norah's dad overhears this. He stops, asks a question. Th The Beaver and Norah's father get into a conversation wit Walter pointing in Porter’s direction. Norah's father looks at Walter like he’s crazy. He starts walk away. Norah and Porter’s eyes finally meet. Her look is not sympathetic. It’s like she doesn’t even know him. And then she’s gone. Porter drops his head, begins to POUND it against the cin block wall. As he goes in’ for another shot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter pounding his head into his own wall.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the THUDS as the stucco breaks away. Porter’s actually breaking out. Through a tiny hole, we can actual see in. Suddenly his eyes appears in the hole, looking out. PUSH IN on the hole as his eye disappears and then his he comes back for another blow, causing more stuccos to brea loose and the hole to widen ever so slightly. Another blown and then suddenly his head disappears follo by the faint sound of him collapsing, unconscious. We hold on the hole, looking into the room from outside. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith waits outside the school. Henry opens his door leaps in. But when the back doors open Meredith stops the other kids cold.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Sorry guys. Not today. Not this week. They stop mid entry, back out, close the doors, She looks Henry. He doesn’t seem to have noticed any of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is working. Meredith opens the door. A moment as sh considers things.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: That’s enough for today.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But, mom, I just got started.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: No more. He thinks about protesting, but gives up. He puts his stu down, walks inside. The way he moves, quiet, uncaring, he’s instantly back to being the old Henry. Meredith looks distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith is on the phone.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Dr. Macy? It’s Meredith Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter is at his locker. Hector walks up.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Look man, we have to talk. Porter sees Norah coming. She’s back in her cheer outfit.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You got the website, right?

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, man, but you don’t understand. My grandma, she’s all- Porter closes his locker, starts toward Norah.

dialogues.speaker: __. PORTER
dialogues.text: Just stick to the story, you’ll be fine. He takes off. Hector throws his hands up in frustration. Porter catches up to Norah.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (cold) Hey. Porter reaches into his bag.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I, uh, finished the speech. A draft anyway. I can always make changes. She stops, takes it.

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: (flat) Thank you. I’m sure it’s great. She looks at him as if she’s not sure why he’s still ther

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t actually have any cash on me, but if you can wait until tomorrow... He looks insulted, confused.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Look, Norah, I’m so sorry. I don’t know if he told you but I called and explained everything to your father and- She looks around. Looks at Porter.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s fine. Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: So, we're okay.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (still flat) We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: ORTER
dialogues.text: Well, maybe we could-

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Look, we’re just on very different paths, okay? In a couple months we'll be on opposite sides of the country anyway, so let’s just stop now while it’s easy.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: That actually sounds harder than just, you know, seeing what appens .

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: No, Porter, you know what was hard? Seeing my parents faces like that. Going back to that house. Bring all that stuff back up, and for what?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Norah, listen-

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I have to go. She sees some other squad girls and joins up with them, blends in, disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter enters from the garage. Meredith is waiting at the table. His original card is the only thing in front of he

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Hello, Love. Meredith doesn’t say anything. She just stares at him.  70.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the trouble? She looks at the card.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: I talked to Dr. Macy, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter, he says you haven't been there in almost a year.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well... that’s... I- She picks up the card.

dialogues.speaker: / MEREDITH
dialogues.text: What is this? What are you doing? Walter says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dr. Macy says you’‘re sick, Walter. Very sick. He said that this sounds like some kind of mania. He says-—

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Dr. Macy, Dr. Macy. Who gives a damn what Dr. Macy says? Why don’t we go down to the office and see what they sa Meredith? Let’s see if they think’ we're sick, yeah? Or let's see if they think maybe Walter is better than he’s ever been. Let’s ask Henry what he thinks. Let’s ask Henry if he feels better about himself when I’m around, if he’s made any new friends, if he’s happier since I showed up. Ask yourself, Meredith. Ask yourself if you can remember how things were. See if you can remember the person you threw out of here and then tell us why youre so worried about getting him back.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: So what are you saying, Walter, you just want to live like this orever? Walking around with a beaver puppet on your hand?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: What would be so wrong with that? I'd say it’s been a pretty smashing success so far.  71. Meredith is stunned. She just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter, you need help. 1 hel ve Tp Eve bod: Help, help, help. Everybo wants him to gee help® See the ex ert. Read the book. Take the pill. Well, Walter finally helped himself. You understand? That’s what I’m here for. He doesn’t need anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter, listen to yourself! This is insane! You’re talking about a fucking puppet!

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: No ou’re talking about a puppet. We're talking about a success! She looks at him, heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Who is ‘we’ Walter? Off his look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter splashes water on his face with his free hand. He stands up and looks himself in the mirror. Slowly, he raises his left hand until he and The Beaver a both staring into the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I know it’s hard, mate, but you can’t let yourself get mixed up. You’ve done what you needed to. You’ve put the past behind you. You’re moving on, and we’re doing geet She’s the one who’s got to et go. And if she can’t then... you've got to let her go. Walter looks troubled by this suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know, I know, but trust me, it’s for the best. What we talked about, blowing it up, starting fresh, a clean slate, well this is what it takes. Anything less and we're back on the road to that hotel room. Is that what you want? Walter shakes his head.  72.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're free, mate. You’ve broken out. All you have to do now is keep moving. Keep moving and never look back. If it’s meant to be, they’11l follow. But that’s up to them. It’s out of our hands. Walter stares at The Beaver for a long beat. Finally, he makes the slightest of nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter steps in. Meredith is sitting on the bed. She look up.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Understand that we love you more than anything. But you’re the one who needs help. This notion of what used to be, it poisons everything, and until you realize that and let it go, it’s just going to continue to make you miserable. We’ve put it behind us and we’re not looking back. We hope you can do the same. But make no mistakes. I’m not going anywhere. Meredith stares at him. SILENCE. She gets UP y slowly wal over, looks into Walter’s eyes. She kisses him on the che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER SITS stoically, The Beaver raised beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEREDITH PACKS clothes into a suitcase. When she moves th suitcase she sees the memory box. She looks at it for a moment. Then she drops it in the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PORTER SWEEPS books into a box. He pauses over the notebo labeled JOURNAL OF SIMILARITIES we saw in the beginning. NEW ANGLE shows the list now numbers in the low 60's.  73. He tosses the notebook into the box. As he’s about to go, he stops, goes to his wall. He yanks down the poster he uses to cover his hole. He puts it in trash, leaves the hole exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is loading pieces of wood into the back of the subu when his mother comes out with bags. She looks at him. He looks at her. She can’t bear to tell him no. Porter comes out, tosses his things in. Without a word he gets in the passenger seat, puts on his belt. He’s ready. As Meredith and Henry are finishing up Walter steps into garage. He stands by the door. Henry rushes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you coming with us?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Another time, mate. Another time.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I want to stay with you. Walter and Meredith exchange glances. These words clearly break her heart.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: You go with your mum, we’ll get it all sorted, yeah? You’ll see, everything’ will be good again real soon.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Henry. It’s time to go. He turns and walks to the car, the same distant, emotionl walk he’s shown us before. Meredith gets in. Henry climbs She starts the car. Then, just as she’s about to back out, Henry leaps out, r to Walter. He throws himself around him, tears streaking his face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I love you, Dad. This hits Walter someplace deep. He’s moved to the verge tears himself. He has to swallow hard to get words out, a when he does, the accent is shaky. Still, it’s The Beaver does the talking.  74.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I love you too, mate. I love you too. Finally, Henry releases him. The Beaver reaches down, mus Henry’s hair. Henry turns, runs back to the car. Once he’s in, Meredith puts it in gear. She pauses a seco she and Walter sharing a final glance. Her expression says she can’t believe he’s really just watching them go. It’s a pleading glance. But then, like that, it hardens. He wants her to let go o the past, that’s exactly what she’s about to do. She turn around, watching the driveway as she backs out. The suburban hits the street, turns, and it’s gone. As so as it clears frame, the garage door starts to come down. Walter watches it until it noisily closes. Then, SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter looks at the dining room table, empty except for h original card.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HENRY’S ROOM Walter stands looking at all the projects, both finished abandoned. Everything is made of wood. There are coffee tables stacked three high. Rocking chair The very beginning of what might have become a boat hull. He picks up a small item near the wall. It’s a beaver fig like the one Walter roughed out and took to work, but muc more polished, refined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stares at the memory box in the trash, the picture spilling out. He can see the top of the one with Meredith his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stares at the hole in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside, we look through the hole and see Walter sta back at us. As we start to pull back he walks closer until it looks l he’1ll lean down and put his face to the hole. Instead, he reaches Porter's bed and simply falls onto it As he disappears from frame we're left looking into Porte empty room until the camera pulls back and the hole becom just a pinprick of light in the wall. And then the lights go out. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPORTER is on mic, a small queue of people in line to enter the store behind her.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Christmas in... May? That’s what some retailers are calling it with Mr. Beaver Woodchopper kits selling out in numbers that remind many of the Tickle Me Elmo phenomenon. Davyco, the company behind Mr. Beaver says they’re doing all they can to keep pace with demand, but admits there have been shortages. interestingly, you may recall that Davyco, which had earlier success with 90's fads Action Jack and Princess Stephanie, lost its founder and CEO Davy Conyers ina highly publicized restaurant choking incident while in the company of a paid escort and since then the company has been in steep decline, hovering on the verge of bankruptcy earlier this year. But thanks to Mr. Beaver, it looks like that won’t be happening anytime soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter flips off the TV as the report ends. He turns to T VP who’s sitting across from him holding a snifter of bra  76. Their voices indicate that they’re a bit on the tipsy sid

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: It’s like a hundred million dollar ad campaign for free. They both LAUGH. The VP takes a sip of his brandy. We see that Walter also has a snifter. It has two straws. puts one to his lips, one to the Beavers, and drinks. The VP shifts in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Speaking of, we've been getting a lot of media requests for you. We've been declining obviously, but if we set up a big conference call we could milk the SER a little without really exposing too much.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Conference call? Don’t be ridiculous, mate. Who’s the biggest request we've had? THE VP. I don’t know. All the morning shows. CNN. CNBC.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Today show then. Set it up.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Sir, the Today show is... on television.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Why are you acting like we've got something to hide, mate? The case is just the opposite. We’ve got a story, not just about the rebirth of a company, but of a man. That’s a powerful tale and we should be looking to tell it wherever they’11 listen.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: It’s just hard to predict how people are going to... react.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: How did you react?

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Well, I was pretty shocked at first.  77.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Of course you were. But I’ve convinced you it’s for the best, have I not? And the rest of the gtatt? How many people have we os

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: So what makes you think I can’t convince them? The VP thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: THE V
dialogues.text: It would certainly be a story.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Damn right. And who better to tell it? The VP nods. He’s coming around on this. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: I have to tell you, in the beginning, I think a lot of us thought this was the beginning of the end. They LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know how you did it, but- He raises his glass. Walter reciprocates. CLINK.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m damn glad you did, and frankly, proud to have been part of it. They both take a drink. A quiet stillness settles. They regard one another for a moment. Then...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I’m going to tell you something. Something I haven’t told anyone else. But it’s something that I think you’re ready to hear. The VP looks honored to be entrusted.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: The truth is... I’m not a puppet. The VP smiles, waiting for the punch line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I’m quite serious, mate. I’m as real as you or Walter. The VP is struggling, still hoping this is a joke. He fee obligated to say something.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: I... don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, dmagine Siamese Twins, but instead of being cut apart, we’ve been put back together. You see? We're a part of a system, something that’s fully integrated, shared. He’s part of me and I’m literally a part of him. We make one another whole. And now that that’s happened, now that we’ve been joined, we couldn't be separated if we wanted to. The VP has given up waiting for the other shoe. He just l uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: I understand, believe me, it’s hard to swallow. Neither of us has the slightest clue how it happened. It would appear that when I breathed life into him, he breathed life into me. I suppose I just wanted you to know it’s not an act, it’s not a gimmick, it’s not a stunt. I’m real, alive, fused. And that’s not going to change. It’s not going to be undone. The VP nods.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Okay. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: It's not that, sir, it’s just very... strange. I’m sure you believe-

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Pull me off.  79.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Come up here and pull me off of Walter’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: That's really not necessary, sir. If you say-

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Come up here and pull me off his goddamned hand. The VP sits stunned for a moment. Finally, he puts down h snifter, moves to the desk. He’s struck by the size of Walter’s bulging left forearm. He looks at Walter for a beat, then puts his hands on The Beaver. He makes the faintest’ of tugging motions.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh come on. Pull. The VP sighs. This time he pulls a little harder. The Bea doesn’t budge.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on dammit! Stop being a pussy!

dialogues.speaker: PULL
dialogues.text: Now this is getting on the VP’s nerves. This time he yank Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the way. Come on! Suddenly, the VP wants to prove to Walter that he’s delusional. He really gets into it. He leans back, he GRUNTS. Nothing. He changes his grip, puts a foot on the desk to brace himself. He STRAINS.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: (as_he pulls) Jesus. What did you, glue this thing?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: (calm) Not a glue on Earth that can do this, mate. That’s what I’ve been telling you. The VP manages to pull Walter a few inches out of his cha but The Beaver doesn’t move at all.  80. Now he’s frustrated, maybe a little creeped out. He begin grab The Beaver every which way as he struggles to pull i off like a dog with a sock in its mouth.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey, not my nose, dammit! Let go of my arm you asshole! Finally, when he’s applied all his effort, something lets and the’vP flies backward across the offi¢e and into the where he collapses. He looks at his hands. Nothing but a couple tiny tufts of ur. He looks across the office. There’s Walter and The Beaver connected as ever. He hasn’t moved it a fraction. The VP has no idea what to think. He’s simply dumbfounded Walter gets up from behind the desk, walks over to him. H extends his right hand, helps the Ve up. An awkward SILENCE when the three of them are face to fac

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You okay to drive?

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: (beat ) Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Good. The VP nods. He turns to go. THE BEAVER foona iD) D) Don’t forget mate. Today show. Set it up. The VP hesitates. He nods again. And he’s gone. When he’s alone, Walter and The Beaver slowly turn, face other. Off their stare down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter slides next to Norah as she’s selecting food.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hey. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Now’s not a good time.  81.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I’ve called, texted, im’d, and it never seems to be a good time.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Maybe you should take that as a hint. As she walks away towards the registers... She stops. She heads

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I read an article about your brother. Turns. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He really was an amazing guy.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: That’s what you wanted to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You said you’d been headed to Stanford forever. You_never said that’s where he was planning on going too.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: So we’re going to the same school. Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Please. The same school. The same classes. The same clubs. If they'd let you on the football team you’d have identical transcripts. for the registers again. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I understand that you feel a certain... responsibility, for what happened. But it’s not your job to replace him. As she’s paying...

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You don’t have a fucking clue what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is if you don’t want to see me, you don’t want to talk to me, that’s fine. But do it because that’s really what you want to do, not because you think it’s what you’re supposed to do.  82.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Where did you get this idea that I’m not doing what I want?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Oh come on. One day you’re this rebel painter and then your brother dies and suddenly you’re making a beeline for valedictorian and Stanford?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: It's called growing up. You should try it. She takes her food, walks away. He falls right into step.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: It's called denial, Norah. You_ guys keep his room hermetically sealed while you build a carbon copy right next door. You feel guilty so you drop your own life and try to take over his. And as _long as you never step out of the footprints, everyone gets to go on pretending it never happened. But you meet somebody and you threaten to live your own life, even for a second, and you freak out. I’m sorry about what happened. I don’t know how Many more ways I can say that, but I’m not your problem, Norah. Your problem is that you have no idea who you really are, and you don’t seem the least bit interested in finding out. You can take all his classes, and give his speeches, and go get his degree if you want, but sooner or later you and your parents are gonna have to face the act that none of that is going to bring your brother back. She stops suddenl turns and SLAPS him. Hard. Drops her tr and puts him on t é ground, hard. The whole room looks up. People stand, crowd in. Some OHH They're all waiting. She looks down at him. She’s teary eyed, but her voice is pure anger.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You want to hear from the real me? Fuck off. She walks away and is immediately embraced by the squad. Porter just sits there until people lose interest, move o He SNAPS the rubber band on his wrist.  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON The VP standing by a monitor watching the back a forth between MATT LAUER and The Beaver. The VP looks like he’s nervous enough to gnaw off a finge

dialogues.speaker: MATT LAUER
dialogues.text: And so what was their reaction the first time you showed up for work like this?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure they thought I was crazy. And justifiably so. shows Matt and Walter on the actual set.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: MATT LAUER
dialogues.text: But that’s not how you saw yourself?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Not at all. Mozart was said to occasionally feel obliged to meow like a cat, but he seemed to get on all right. Walter’s approach was unconventional because conventional approaches proved worthless. What’s important is not how someone looks or speaks, but what results from their actions and words. I think the overwhelming success of what was recently a failing company says all it needs to about Walter's judgement.

dialogues.speaker: MATT LAUER
dialogues.text: And this all began as a way of dealing with depression?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Sometimes, Matt, we reach a point where in order to go on, we have to wipe the slate clean. Put the problems, failures, and fear of the past behind us and begin again from scratch.

dialogues.speaker: MATT LAUER
dialogues.text: Well, I think the obvious question is, why would you choose this particular way to attack that problem?  84.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Because sometimes the thing that’s holding you back is the very idea of who you are. We begin our lives believing that anything is possible and then slowly we let the walls close in until all we can see is this very narrow range of possibilities. We say things like ‘oh I’m not the kind of person who could do this or that, who could look this way or that way, who could say these things or those.’ We start to see who we are as a box that we're trapped inside, and however we try to escape; resolutions, therapy, drugs, classes, it simply reels us back in. And I believe the only way to truly break out is to get rid of that box all together. If thinking and acting and being a certain way, a certain ‘person’, has resulted in unhappiness, why would you keep doing it? Taking your future into your hands and starting over isn’t crazy. Crazy is being miserable and still doing Yehe same things day after day. Walter had made a mess of his life, and until he freed himself from his failures, he was cut off from the potential for the wonderful things you see happening to him now. I’d suggest to you that there are many © others out there being crushe under the weight of the boxes they’ve put themselves in. And whether those Best ple pick up a puppet or not is eside the point. What’s important is that they find a way to start over from a point where they really and truly believe that anything is possible. Because it’s been my experience that if you can do Yehat, what follows will only confirm the notion. Matt thinks on this for a moment. He seems surprised, NEW ANGLE shows the VP watching, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MATT LAUER
dialogues.text: (on monitor) Well, I want thank you for joining us this morning. The VP can’t believe they’ve pulled it off. He looks elat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter stands and shakes hands with Matt Lauer.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a picture of Walter Black. A hopelessly depressed individual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and The VP step out and are immediately mobbed by crowd.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who becomes a beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER AND THE BEAVER on Good Morning America.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who becomes a phenomenon. WALTER AND THE BEAVER on CNBC.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It turns out that in fact, there are a lot people out there. People looking for answers, for help, for change. WALTER AND THE BEAVER on LARRY KING.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And they’re desperate enough to listen - WALTER AND THE BEAVER on A DAYTIME TALK SHOW. The audienc CLAPS wildly.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - even if it’s a puppet doing the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shelf labeled MR. BEAVER WOODCHOPPER KIT has a sign rea SOLD OUT.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Retailers find that not only are they constantly out of Mr. Beaver’s woodchopper kits-  86. A rack of stuffed puppets is being picked over by a crowd people.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But that there’s a sudden, seemingly insatiable, interest in plush stuffed puppets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see several people walking down the street, briefcase one hand, beaver puppet on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see various people with various puppets. An Alligator. Pig. A Bear. There’s an older woman with an Octopus.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Andrmed with the ability to make a fresh start people suddenly find themselves able to do all sorts of things they’d previously thought impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN stands across a desk from a man. She’s yelling at with the aid of an Elephant puppet on her left hand.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Others get the strength to leave troubled relationships. The GIRLFRIEND responds by raising her own puppet to spea

dialogues.text: We see an ELDERLY MEXICAN WOMAN and pull back to reveal Hector. We pull back further to reveal that Hector is wea a Kangaroo puppet.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And some even start their new lives by confessing to the crimes they'd committed in their old ones. Pull back further to reveal the PRINCIPAL. As Hector fini he looks to the elderly woman. She nods approvingly.  87. The Principal gets_a look of sinister satisfaction. He tu toward the far wall. REVEAL Porter, sitting in a chair, sold down the river by puppet.

So while Walter is signing a deal to write exactly the kind of book he’d once thrown away. Meredith looks away and finds herself staring at the bags under ANN’s chair. She freezes. ANGLE ON the bag to reveal a small plush puppet sticking ANN sees Meredith looking and slyly scoots the bag furthe under her chair.

dialogues.text: Porter is told that he not only won't walk at his own graduation, Norah walks by. She stops as if she wants to say somethin but decides she can’t. She moves on. INT. ANN’S KITCHEN ANGLE ON a table where a single opened envelope and a one page letter are sitting. THE BEAVER (V.O. But that Brown apparently takes academic fraud quite seriously. ANGLE ON the floor where Porter lies as if he’s been shot

dialogues.text: Walter is giving a local interview. His head is on the ta as if sleeping, only The Beaver is upright. The Beaver SLAPS him on the head. Walter sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
