dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s the tail on a dog, ignored and irrelevant, unless he happens to knock something over. The Beaver dispenses advice. The audience is rapt.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and The Beaver glare at one another in one of thos mirrors surrounded by light bulbs. Neither says a word. They just stare one another down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks in and drops several big bags of luggage. Exhausted, he collapses on the bed without changing cloth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter wakes, still in the same clothes. He looks over at Beaver who is on the pillow next to him, eyes covered wit the eye mask. Walter carefully turns to his night stand and with his fr hand he grabs his cell phone. He scrolls to Meredith, dia He puts the phone to his ear, waits. Then...

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: (filter, groggy) Hello. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: _. WALTER
dialogues.text: gybispering) Meredith. It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I... I don’t- Suddenly, Walter’s left hand rises off the pillow, the Beaver’s head jerking around, startled.

dialogues.speaker: _THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: What’s going on? What’s- The Beaver shakes the eye mask off, looks at Walter on th phone.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Who are you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter? Walter, talk to me.  90.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Hang up. Hang up right now. The Beaver and Walter look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Walter please-

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I have to go. He hangs up. A long SILENCE. Then... Walter SMASHES himself in the face with The Beaver. A moment as Walter stares, shocked, at The Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: What the hell are you thinking? Instead of answering, Walter suddenly grabs the Beaver an WHACKS it against his night stand. A brawl is on. If this plays with any humor at the start it very quickly disappears. This isn’t Liar Liar. Walter is truly self destructive and the damage he does is real. The Beaver hoists a lamp, SMASHES it over Walter. Blood trickles down his forehead. Walter puts The Beaver against the door jam, SLAMS the do on him repeatedly. He/They SCREAM. They tumble into the dresser, knocking it over. Walter PUNCHES The Beaver into the wall head first, leavi small holes in the drywall. The Beaver picks up the phone and CLOBBERS Walter across face with it. Walter is reeling. Walter falls backward into the wall. Pictures fall. The Beaver grabs Walter by the throat, presses him agains the wall, choking him. Walter struggles, turns red. He’s literally, successfully denying himself oxygen. The veins pop out. The eyes roll. He slumps and releases his own throat, crumbling into a p unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. WALTER'S BEDROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Walter wakes, GASPING slightly.  91. The blood has begun to dry in lines running down his face His eye is badly swollen and darkening. He raises The Beaver. One of its eyes is smashed. Lots of is missing. One arm is torn slightly. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, mate. Look at us. Walter doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Haven't I delivered exactly what we talked about? Walter nods.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it’s hard, but you have to trust me. We’ve done the right thing at every turn. We’ve come so far, mate. There’re so many good things ahead. Now is not the time to start looking over your shoulder, yeah? Walter thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I miss them.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: You think I don’t? But they want you to go back to something that’s oisonous, destructive. Open that oor again, even a crack, you'll end up right where you started. I know you don’t want that, no matter how much you miss them. And I’m not going to let it happen. Walter nods.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're a team, Walter. The only ones we can really count on are each other. I told you it was going to be hard, yeah? But look at what we've done. And we're just getting started. (beat ) What’s important is that you know I’m always going to be here for you. Today, tomorrow, forever. Forever, yeah? Walter looks at The Beaver. He nods, wipes his face. A de breath.  92.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I don’t think I can sleep anymore. Maybe we should work on something for a while.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Sure mate. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter and The Beaver work at the bench. SAWING. SANDING. HAMMERING. GLUING. Something is taking shape. A box, but it’s longer and skinnier than the memory boxes we’ve seen before. They work on a lid, They round the edges. It’s incredibly elaborate, impressive, artful. They step back, regard the work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter has opened the garage door. He’s resting on the concrete facing out where the sun is just beginning to ri ANGLE ON Walter and The Beaver, quietly, reverently stari at the dawn. Over his shoulder we can see the workbench and the finish box, lid up. After a moment, The Beaver turns back toward the workbenc then looks at Walter. The bench. Walter. Something sinks

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER
dialogues.text: Walter? Walter doesn’t look away from the sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walter. Don’t. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walter, you have to listen to me. You will be lost. Walter gets up. He turns and heads back inside.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you'll get them back? It doesn’t work that way. There is no going back.  93. Walter presses the button. The garage door starts to come down, blocking out the sun.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It_won’t even be like before. It will be worse Walter. Much worse. Walter walks over to the box. He holds The Beaver over it It’s a perfect fit. They’ve made a little coffin.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEAVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re going to end up alone, Walter. All alone. Don’t do it. Don't. Walter stares at The Beaver for a long beat. It seems lik might be convinced. Then...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. suddeniy he flips on the TABLE SAW. He puts his left arm the table and grabs the saw handle with his right.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He pulls the saw forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stare at the innocuous looking garage door, just like others on the street, as we hear The Beaver’s SCREAM and sound of the SAW digging in. Then... SILENCE. A man walks by with his dog, oblivious. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: We hear the BEEP BEEP BEEP of a large truck backing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal a garbage truck backing up to a garbage pile. It l its rear, dumps its load. As the garbage cascades out we see that among the usual b and detritus there are dozens of discarded puppets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shelf with copies of THE RESET BUTTON by Walter and The Beaver are marked 90% off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shelf with the Mr. Beaver Woodchopper Kits is now ful stocked, ignored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VP appears on CNBC.

dialogues.speaker: THE VP
dialogues.text: Absolutely, Mr. Beaver provided us with_a much needed revenue boost, but I think in my tenure it’s going to be time for us to return focus to the products and brands _that got us going and made us great

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON the television where the same DAYTIME TALK SHOW who earlier had Walter on is addressing her audience.

dialogues.speaker: DAYTIME TALK SHOW HOST
dialogues.text: (on TV) While we standby the message we were trying to communicate, it’s clear that the messenger was not well and I want to make clear that we do not endorse any of the tactics he may have discussed here or elsewhere. If anyone feels like the might hurt themselves please ca. - ANGLE ON the couch, revealing Porter sprawled, barely conscious. He changes the channel. Meredith walks in. She stands in front of the TV. Turns i off. He doesn’t seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Come on. Get up. He doesn’t budge.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to go in if don’t want to, but I’m not eaving you here to sleep all day.  95. She walks over, starts to physically pull him up. He rema imp.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Mom. She drops him. He goes horizontal again. She looks exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Porter, please. A long beat. He slowly gets to his feet. He raises his ar as if to say, happy?

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. Get some shoes on.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I’m up okay? But I’m not going. She looks at him. Considers this. Henry comes in, excited

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Are we going? A beat. She decides Porter is a lost cause.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Henry takes off toward the garage. Meredith looks at Port one more time.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do something. Go outside. Take a walk. See that girl. Steal _a car. I don’t care. Just get out of the house, okay? He nods. She heads for the garage. Porter stands still as we hear the Suburban rumble away. he heads for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter walks in. He heads straight for his bed, falls int it, pulls a pillow over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, wearing hospital issue white, is seated across fr DOCTOR BANKS. They’re working with a prosthetic hand. Walter raises it, looks at it. He seems pleased. The doct seems pleased.  96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is in group, surrounded by other patients in white each with varying grips on reality. DOCTOR BANKS is at th center of the semi-circle. Walter raises his prosthetic to talk. Before he’s called NURSE enters.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Walter? Family’s here. Walter beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter sits across the table from Meredith and Henry. Hen passes across a gift bag. Walter looks at it, surprised. He opens it up. He pulls o small hand-carved replica of a brain.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mom says yours got broken. Walter LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. This will come in handy. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: So, are you crazy? Meredith begins to protest, but Walter’s up to it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Maybe. But we’re working on it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Does that mean you can come home? He and Meredith share a glance.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: We're... working on it. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: They... said you’re doing well.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Eat, sleep, talk, don’t hurt yourself. Not the toughest gig.  97. Despite the circumstances Walter seems relatively upbeat, together.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How's Porter? Meredith rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: He won’t do anything. I’m trying to et him to take community college or a year, but he won’t even talk about it. He just lays there. Walter nods, considering this deeply.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s got to do something. We can’t go a year like this.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Sounds like he was too busy to come along. She suddenly finds herself staring at the prosthetic hand

dialogues.speaker: . MEREDITH
dialogues.text: He’s just... he’1l come around. Walter nods. A long silence. Walter begins to run his han over the contours of the brain. They all find themselves staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Walter hug goodbye. Meredith and Walter follow suit. He’s escorted through a door, waves goodbye. As Meredith and Henry walk away a Doctor falls into step.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Black? I’m Doctor Banks. We spoke on the phone? She nods, but doesn’t stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, as I said, we're very pleased with Walter’s progress. He’s on medication, but we’ve got the dosing at & low level and he’s responded very favorably. No signs of delirium or suicidal ideation. And he’s been very active in group and with the other patients. Frankly, he’s well liked. Meredith nods, but she’s still walking. If anything, she’ walking faster.  98.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I said on the phone, I think that with some supervision and regular therapy there’s no reason- They reach the doors. Meredith cuts him off, pulls out he keys. She hands them to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Henry. Here. Go wait in the car. I‘1ll just be another minute. Henry looks at her, takes the keys, walks out. Meredith turns back to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS
dialogues.text: As I was saying, I’m comfortable releasing him to your care if-

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Doctor, I’m... I don’t think we’re ready for that. The doctor nods, takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS
dialogues.text: I understand. When you are ready, I think it would be beneficial for him to have his family around him. She thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: How long will you keep him?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS
dialogues.text: Well, it would be several months before we could sign him out under his own supervision, but-

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: That's fine. We’ll work on figuring out what to do with him after that. A beat as he grasps the situation. He hands her some pape

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR BANKS
dialogues.text: In case you change your mind. She takes the papers, puts them in her purse. She heads o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is seated on a couch with other patients facing a but Walter's eyes are on the window.  99. ANGLE ON the window where he can see Meredith getting int the suburban. She backs up, drives on. ANGLE ON Walter as he raises his prosthetic hand, regards FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: OVER BLACK
dialogues.text: A DOORBELL rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith opens the door to reveal Norah. They look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith KNOCKS on Porter's door. No response. She tries handle. It’s locked.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: Porter? Porter are you up? Your friend is here. Norah. A long beat. Then suddenly the sound of his radio BLARING Meredith turns to Norah. Norah smiles. She understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter sits on his bed, staring at the door. He’s clearly conflicted, but he doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith and Norah are walking away when suddenly the mus stops. Norah and Meredith pause, look back. Porter's door opens. He sticks his head out. A long beat as Norah and Porter look at one another. Then without a word, she turns and heads back towards his room Meredith watches, satisfied, then heads downstairs.  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter sits on his bed. Norah sits across. There’s a bit breeze outside, and even though the poster is once again the hole in the wall, it RATTLES occasionally as the wind comes through the small opening to the outside. They can’t seem to decide who should start. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: So how was graduation?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Honestly? I’d say the fact that you weren’t allowed to be there worked out in your favor. He just nods.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted you to know, I didn’t end up using your speech. At the last minute I got this idea that it was more important for the words to be mine than to be good. A beat. Then quietly...

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Well... you still owe me 150 bucks. She smiles, the first break in the ice.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: You were right, you know? About no one really p. paying attention. When I finally decided that I had to write the thing myself I thought I suddenly had this great insight that was going to knock everyone's socks off. It was all about how every time you breathe you get two atoms that were breathed by every person who’s ever lived. Julius Caesar, James Dean, Queen Elizabeth. You’ve heard that right? He nods.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So anyway, that meant that two of the atoms in everyone’s breath also came from my brother. And even though he was gone, he was still this tiny part of us all. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. 101.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what he’d want us to remember was not that his name was on two atoms in every breath, but that every breath was our chance to put our own signature on a trillion little pieces of the future.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, let me give you some advice, should you ever find yourself giving a speech to a thousand eighteen year olds dying to oO party - Dead people and atoms? a! Pro y not the topics you want to lead with.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I mean, I can’t tell you how many times I pictured all of that playing out, you know? Me on stage, giving this amazing speech, everyone in awe, my parents weeping, and even my brother, like, sitting on some cloud, looking down and smiling. (beat) But it wasn’t like that at all. I mean people clapped, but mostl. because it was over. Durban, the third time’s the charm senior, he got the real ovation.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: And your parents?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Oh, very pappy Very proud. We have roughly 4000 photos of the event.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: And your brother?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Not a cloud in the sky. Porter nods.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you think that I’ve been trying to replace him somehow, and I’m sure that’s part of it, but the truth is, I didn’t know him that well when he was alive. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was always something I was trying to separate myself from, not get closer to. And by the time I realized how stupid that was, he wasn’t around. So I didn’t become this overachieving valedictorian to bring him back. I did it because every time I did something he'd done, every time someone looked at me and saw a little bit of my brother, it felt like we were getting closer. Like I was finally getting to know him, even though he was gone. But the flip side is that after eighteen years I feel like I know my dead brother a lot better than I know myself. And I guess I just wanted to say... I’m working on it. A beat, then she stands.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I should go. We’re doing some packing.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (as he stands) Really dying to get to Stanford,

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: Well, no, actually. It’s not that kind’ of Packing. I ended up deferring Stanford for a year. I figured I’d take some time, drive around, see if that’s really where I‘m supposed to be. Or something like that. Like I said, I’m working on it. Porter's surprised.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Wow. Good for you. How are your parents with that?

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: (beat ) . ; We’re all working on it. She starts to go and then stops, reaches into her purse a pulls out some papers.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. I almost forgot. I wanted to give you this. He takes the pages.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s your speech.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, this is just a print out. I've still got it on my drive.

dialogues.speaker: NORAH
dialogues.text: I know. I just thought... I mean, I know your whole deal was that you could sound like anyone, but the more I thought about it, the more I realized, this isn’t me ‘talking. It’s you. You wrote it. raqast wondered if you'd ever really sat down and read it. 103. He’s not sure what to say. She looks at him, smiles. She hesitates, then steps over, kisses him. It’s short, but it says what it needs to. sweet, She walks out. He looks at the pages in his hand. The win RATTLES the poster on his wall. He takes a seat on his bed, unfolds the pages. As he begi to read...

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Faculty, students, families, I’m here today because I’m supposed to tell you something about tomorrow. I’m supposed to remind you that it’s the first day of the rest of your life, and inspire you to seize the infinite array of possibilities that_have suddenly become available. I’m supposed to tell you that you can_do anything you dare to dream as long a you just listen to your heart and fo low your rainbow. But I can’t do that. Because it’s not true. INT. NORAH'S BROTHER’S ROOM We see the walls covered in trophies, awards.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE reveals that Norah and her parents are packing things into boxes.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The truth is, there ate people out there in big government buildings and insurance agencies whose job is to predict the future. They don’t know you or me, don’t know a thing about our hopes and dreams, and frankly they don’t care. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But still they’re hunched over their computers, crunching numbers, and without ever having asked you what you want to be when you grow BP, t hey know not only what kind of b you 11 have, and how much money you’ 1 make, but whether you’1ll be married or have kids, where and how you'll live, and even roughly when you'll die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Walter in the ward. He’s playing a game with other patients. They LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when you look at all their statistics, all their data, all their predictions, the future looks less like something you get to write than something you simply get to show up for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Meredith and Walter visiting together. It’s tender quiet. They hold hands.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So instead of deluding you, instead of offering you cliches and platitudes, I tgats going to give it to you straight. Most of us will be average. That’s why they call it average, because the majority of us end up there. And according to the statistics, this is what the future holds for the average person in this class: You'll die before you're 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meredith stands talking to the doctor at the door again. Again she leaves alone.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You'll be married, but you’1l also get divorced. You'll suffer from at east one mae jredical problem.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You’1l work out of an office, live in a modest home, and never make more than 100 thousand dollars a year. Doesn’t really sound that exciting does it? Certainly doesn’t sound like the life they promise in most graduation speeches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is happily back at work, surrounded by lumber if no people

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But what if I told you that the person described in that scenario was not someone from this class, but Albert Einstein. Because while he may have been one of the most famous minds in history, according to the numbers, he was as average as they come. Life ft down Ehe job, house, all right down the dle. So’ how come average is nding the last thing you think of when you hear the name Einstein?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NORAH’S ROOM Norah is packing her own things.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O. -)
dialogues.text: It’s because even if 1 the statistics, all the predictions, all the numbers are true, they don’t really tell you anythin about what your life will be Tike. What it will be worth. fihate it will mean. The formulas, equations, scores, and data, they’re just pieces of the story.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. NORAH’S DRIVEWAY We see her and her parents loading her car up with her st

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: And if you put_them all together, they don’t really tell you who you'll be because people are more than the SUMORE jrheir parts.  PORTER (V.O.) (cont) I can’t stand here and tell you that anything is possible, because it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON all his books on genetics. 106.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: NEW ANGLE shows him packing them up. He rests on a box, looking down, toying with the rubber band on his wrist. H eyes his Journal of Similarities list.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your name is already written in a big book somewhere and certain things, whether you like them or not, have already been jotted down next to it. And Maybe ePoss things can’t be changed. But what your name will ultimately mean, what it will cause others to think of, to remember, to feel, that is something that’s hot yet written, something that cannot be predicted. It's something that only you can control. You don! ‘t_have to believe anythin is possible for tomorrow be the first day of the rest of your life. You pust have to believe hat when all the math is done, there’s still something that can’t be accounted for. That thing is what makes you, you. And all you have to do now, is create it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Porter sits alone on a bench, nervous. He keeps eying the entrance. Finally, he gets to his feet, heads in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter and Walter sit across from one another. Walter loo peaceful. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: So... you're going to be okay? Walter nods, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I think so.  107.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You think so? Walter smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: They’ re just doctors son. They can’t see the future.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: But they have a good feeling, right? They feel like you’re probably going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It’s not up to them. A long beat. Porter works up to asking the question he re wants the answer to.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What about me? Am I going to be okay? Declarative, and without hesitation...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You’re going to be fine. Porter scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: First, Grandpa and now you. I mean- Again, definitively.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You’re going to be fine. Porter’s tone changes. He’s not combative. He really want the answer.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: How do you know that? Walter waits until Porter looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Because it’s up to you. Another long beat. Then... Porter reaches down, pulls the rubber band off his wrist. puts it around his father’s prosthetic. They look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter gets into the back seat, closes the door. He’s emotional, unsure what he’s feeling. NEW ANGLE reveals Henry sitting beside him, whittling qui on a piece of wood. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Are they coming?

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just have to finish some paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens. Meredith and Walter come out togeth Walter takes a moment to look around, and then out of now Henry comes streaking across the grounds, wraps himself around Walter’s leg. He hoists the boy onto his shoulders. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah’s parents wave goodbye as she drops her loaded car gear, pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norah pulls onto the road, rolls down the window. Wind in hair, she hits the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter’s not here. The room is missing things, even if we not sure what they are. What we notice is that on the far wall, where the hole wa is Norah’s painting, the one she said she always liked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter sits outside, alone. Thinking. Waiting. Watching. VERY SLOWLY PULL BACK to reveal he’s sitting on a fully loaded backpack. Suddenly, a huge smile spreads across his face as he spot what he’s looking for.  109. NEW ANGLE as Norah pulls up in her loaded car. She presse button. The trunk opens. NEW ANGLE as Porter throws his bag in the trunk. NEW ANGLE as Porter hugs his family. — WALTER (V.0.) This is a picture of Walter Black. Henry gives Porter a wooden compass. He pats his younger brother on the head.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A once hopelessly depressed individual. Porter and Norah get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who had to become a beaver. INT. NORAH’S CAR Porter puts the compass in the middle of the dash. The tw them look at one another. They LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car starts. The windows come down. Porter and Norah e stick an arm out to wave goodbye as they drive away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who had to become a phenomenon. ANGLE ON the family. They raise their arms, wave goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So that ultimately this could just be a picture- ANGLE ON Walter’s prosthetic waving goodbye, Porter’s rub band around its wrist.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - of Walter Black. FADE OUT.
